HEADLINE: A CONVERSATION WITH: RUSH HOLT;
At Last, a Politician Who Knows Quantum Mechanics

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA DREIFUS 

 BODY:
One of the upsets of the Nov. 3 election was the defeat of the incumbent Republican, Michael Pappas, in New Jersey's 12th Congressional District by Dr. Rush Holt, who had never held elected office. Mr. Pappas was best known nationally as the Congressman who once sang, on the floor of the House of Representatives, a tribute he had composed to the special prosecutor, "Twinkle, twinkle, Kenneth Starr, now we know how brave you are."
Dr. Holt, 50, a physicist, was the assistant director of Princeton Plasma Physics Laboratory. He will join Representative Vernon J. Ehlers, Republican of Michigan, as one of two physicists serving in Congress. 
 "We're talking about starting a bipartisan physics caucus," Representative-elect Holt, a Democrat, joked recently in an interview at his mother's Washington apartment.
 Q. In your campaign, you received contributions from 14 Nobel Prize winners. Did they support you because you're likely to put science issues onto the legislative agenda?
 A. I must tell you, we didn't try to recruit Nobel Prize winners to my campaign. But word went out in the community that I was running, and some scientists told others and they gave. My campaign staff was very excited by these contributors and they wrote them a letter and asked if it was O.K. to use their names. My staff picked up on that . . . just like they picked up on the fact that I'd been on "Jeopardy" six times.
 Q. How much did you win?
 A. About $5,500 and a car. This was back in the 1970's when the categories were worth $10 and $20.
But back to my campaign: To be honest, science was not much of a factor in it. I would talk about what a scientist could bring to Congress, but issues of science did not seem to move most voters. Occasionally, I'd meet a voter who said he'd like to see someone in Congress who "really understood quantum mechanics."
But most people cared more about health care, Social Security, education -- issues that they felt affected their daily lives, and I tried to address those.
 Q. Now that you've won, do you intend to be the science community's point man on the Hill?
 A. I can't help but be, yes.
 Q. Are you starting a trend, trading laboratory for legislature?
 A. With all due respect to lawyers, we need more diversity among legislators. I think more scientists should get involved in public policy. But many say: "Politics is dirty. There's too much compromising."
You know the first question everyone asks me is why would a scientist leave a perfectly good job at a major research lab to go into "that muck." But for me, politics wasn't such a big step. This is the first office that I've run for, but I've worked on Capitol Hill in the early 1980's in the office of Congressman Bob Edgar as a science, defense and education adviser. I worked at the State Department during the Bush Administration, doing arms control.
 Q. How do you think your father, the late Rush Holt Sr., a Senator from West Virginia, would have felt about your career change?
 A. I don't think he'd be particularly impressed or pleased with my election, although I showed some skill as a candidate. I think his satisfaction would come if he saw that I was really using the office to accomplish good for people.
My father passionately fought for good government. . . . Ever since my election, I'm getting letters from people in West Virginia who say, "Your father was a hero of mine." He's been dead 45 years, but he's still remembered because he took stands. In fact, he was defeated for re-election in 1940 because although elected as a New Dealer, he fought with Roosevelt on a number of issues.
Last week, during an orientation session the Democrats had for new members of Congress, one of the Congressional leaders said to us, the freshmen, "If you're not prepared to leave Congress over a principle, then you should leave now." I thought that was an interesting statement. So we'll see. . . .
 Q. Why is it important that there be scientists in Congress?
 A. It's not that scientists have a corner on the truth, but a science background is important for understanding the limitations of some policies. Scientists are in a position to define what is possible. There are examples where policy makers promote programs that just are . . . fallacious, that essentially are prohibited by the laws of science. Legislative calls for a space-based Star Wars system had some aspects of this.
 Q. Speaker Newt Gingrich, who is retiring, is said to be a big science buff. Did he support science?
 A. One of the first things Gingrich did was to abolish the Office of Technology Assessment, an agency that advised Congress on science and technology, thus saying in effect, "We don't want scientists telling us what we don't want to hear." After that, I found it very hard to accept Gingrich's claim that he was the champion of science and technology.
 Q. Would you like to see the office re-established?
 A. I don't know what the political possibilities on that are. But I do believe we have to increase the emphasis on science in the government. If there's a slogan on the wall, it should read, "It's productivity, stupid!"
The way our economy is able to provide for its people is through productivity and that comes from educational training and new ideas. The new ideas, primarily that's research and development. So things such as R and D tax credits are very important. If you look to industry, industries more and more are pulling back on research. Economists will argue how much Government funding of research and development leads or follows corporate research and development. I'm inclined to think it leads. But either way, we need more of it.
Take energy research. We're spending more than $500 billion dollars a year on energy and we're not spending 1 percent of that on research into alternatives. Whether you're a cobbler or a tinman if you see that your raw materials are in jeopardy, you extend some effort to find new sources. The point is that our supplies are in jeopardy, and our means of producing energy are environmentally damaging and yet we're paying little attention to alternatives.
 Q. We've heard you'll be advocating reforms in science education.
 A. Well, yes. Science education should not just be for future scientists, but for all kids. We should get away from this idea that in 10th grade you do biology, in 11th chemistry, and if you stick it out long enough, you do physics in the 12th. It should be all mixed up. And we should be teaching science in a way that's integrated with other disciplines -- literature, social studies.
 Q. How did you get interested in science?
 A. I think when I was in elementary school a book on dinosaurs and fossils got me interested, and I decided then I would be a scientist. My mother was a biology teacher and I'd borrow her books. She had a master's in zoology. After my father died, she taught at a junior college for a couple of years. Then, later, she became Secretary of State in West Virginia and she never got back to science. But while she was still teaching, I often went to the building where my mother was teaching and played around with the chemicals.
I didn't know at the time how dangerous it was to play with mercury. But it sure was fun.
 Q. Back to your recent campaign. When you heard Congressman Pappas singing "Twinkle, twinkle, Kenneth Starr" on C-Span, what was your first reaction?
 A. That we should rethink our media budget. I thought, every voter in the district should have the opportunity to hear that.
 Q. Would you say, if you were rewriting Machiavelli's "The Prince" one of your new rules might be "Never sing on C-Span?"
 A. Yeah. I think Al D'Amato also sang. What was it? "Old MacDonald Had a Farm." And I think Charles Schumer took a page from our campaign with resurrecting an old Al D'Amato song. And he's now Senator-elect Schumer.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The son of a Senator, Rush Holt of New Jersey's 12th Congressional District will double the membership of the House physics caucus. (Michael Geissinger for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Editorial Observer;
Faith in Stocks: The Dow Hits a Record High

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
Wall Street panicked this summer, but Main Street doubted the sky was really going to fall. So far, at least, those who kept their heads -- or at least their stocks -- have done better than those who sold.
Indexes of big American stocks, including the Dow Jones industrials and the Standard & Poor's 500, set records yesterday. Smaller stocks and junk bonds are showing new life. 
 What's going on? Wall Street analysts list a number of causes. The Federal Reserve cut interest rates three times, reassuring investors that it was determined to avoid a recession. Corporate takeovers are back in vogue, Brazil was bailed out, and the election assured that President Clinton would keep his job.
Such explanations have validity, but they miss the most important part of the story. Individual investors were never as fearful as Wall Street that Asia's woes would affect this country's economy. Russia's default on its debt came as a shock to professional investors, as did the collapse of John Meriwether's hedge fund, Long-Term Capital Management. But back on Main Street, investors generally couldn't buy hedge funds -- Long-Term Capital required a minimum investment of $10 million -- and had not invested in Russia either. To be sure, mutual funds that invest primarily in American stocks suffered withdrawals of $6.6 billion in August, but all of that money and more came back in September. The initial public offering business is again strong, and speculation in Internet stocks is hotter than ever.
All this reflects the widespread belief that stocks are now, and always will be, the best long-term investment. The spread of that gospel has had important effects on how the stock market relates to the economy. Back when most investors thought that stocks could fall as well as rise, and deemed it important to try to anticipate those moves, the stock market usually began to fall months before a recession began. But in 1990, the plunge in prices began in the same month as the recession.
Now it is quite possible that the stock market will peak not before, or even simultaneous with, the economy. Instead, stocks may keep rising until evidence of a real recession is clear not just to those who follow economic statistics but to all those people on Main Street who have so far shown such faith in stocks.
Then, perhaps, we will see if the faith can endure a bear market. Such a market is not indicated by a fall of 20 percent or any other arbitrary amount, but by continued declines, quarter after quarter, in stock prices. By that measure, the last bear market ended in 1982, long before most current investors took their first plunge into stocks.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Rally Produces Records as Mergers Feed Enthusiasm

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
Stock prices vaulted to record levels yesterday, furthering a recovery that as recently as two months ago seemed nearly unthinkable.
"I thought we were in the most serious correction since 1990, but I never thought or wrote that the bull market was over," said Byron R. Wien, United States equity strategist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Company. "Now it seems all of that is behind us." 
 The Dow Jones industrial average rose 214.72 points, or 2.34 percent, to 9,374.27. The record is the first since July 17, when the Dow closed at 9,337.97.
Since Aug. 31, when the Dow stood at 7,539.07 after a steep slide, the blue-chip gauge has risen more than 24 percent. For the year, the Dow is up 18.54 percent and has a chance of rising more than 20 percent for a fourth consecutive year, something never accomplished before.
Broader averages also climbed.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index set a record, rising 24.66 points, or 2.12 percent, to 1,188.21. The Nasdaq composite index did not reach a new high but posted the biggest percentage gain yesterday, rising 49.21 points, or 2.55 percent, to 1,977.42. And the Russell 2000 index of smaller-company issues gained 3.86 points, or nearly 1 percent, to 398.15.
Yesterday's action was energized by a daily record for the number of mergers and acquisitions valued at $1 billion or more.
The merger announcements not only prompted investors to change estimates of how much companies were worth but also indicated coming declines in the number of shares available for trading.
"This may be a supply-demand story, where demand for stocks is rising and the supply of stock is reduced as one company after another merges," said Hugh Johnson, chief investment officer at the First Albany Corporation. "The flow of money into mutual funds is fairly strong, and there is pressure on managers to put that money to work."
Two deals seemed to be catalysts for broad swaths of stocks.
News that Bankers Trust may be close to accepting an $8.9 billion offer from Deutsche Bank of Germany heightened interest in financial-services and bank stocks. And word that America Online may acquire Netscape Communications for $4 billion in stock powered Internet and other technology stocks.
Among financial companies, J. P. Morgan gained 6 1/4, to 115 7/8. American Express was up 4 3/8, to 108 15/16. Merrill Lynch jumped 4 3/8, to 76. And Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette rose 3 9/16, to 42 3/4.
Netscape was the most active stock, gaining 2 3/4, to 41 15/16. America Online gained 4 3/8, to 89 1/4.
Other Internet stocks also surged, and analysts said the group, which has seen meteoric gains in recent weeks, was ripe for a steep correction. Yahoo and Amazon.com both became $200 stocks yesterday. Yahoo rose 30 7/16, to 221 7/16. And Amazon.com gained 37 3/8, to 218.
"The performance of the Internet stocks is an unsettling sign," Mr. Wien said.
Still, more-established technology shares also had a very good day. I.B.M. rose 6 7/16, to 166 9/16. Microsoft jumped 5 9/16, to 119 3/16. And Intel closed at 113 9/16, up 1 1/2.
After yesterday's big price moves, Mr. Wien said that according to his calculations, stocks were about 10 percent overvalued. By contrast, in the middle of July the market was 20 percent overvalued, he said.
Nonetheless, the market's recovery, which has been buttressed by three cuts in interest rates by the Federal Reserve, has left many longtime Wall Street hands grasping for historical parallels.
"At this point we are in new ground," said Laszlo Birinyi, who heads his own market research firm. "At the beginning of the year, I said my target for the Dow was 10,000 by the end of 1998. If anyone had asked when the market went through what now looks like a corrective blip, I would have said my new target would have been about 9,000. I am surprised the 10,000 figure came back on the table" for this year.

Treasury Prices Fall
By Bloomberg News
 Prices of Treasury bonds fell for the first time in four days as stocks rallied and Merck & Company sold $500 million of long-term debt, drawing away demand from ultrasafe Government securities.
It is "a continuation of the reverse of the flight to quality," said Edgar Peters, who oversees $16 billion at Panagora Asset Management in Boston.
"A lot of people who bought bonds are dumping them and buying stock," he said.
The 30-year Treasury bond fell 19/32 , to 9930/32 . The yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 5.25 percent from 5.22 percent.
Investors are showing greater demand for stocks and the riskier fixed-income securities since the Federal Reserve trimmed its target rate for overnight loans between banks -- known as the Federal funds rate -- by a quarter-point, to 4.75 percent, last Tuesday.
Many investors are also favoring corporate bonds over Treasuries, wagering that the Fed's three rate cuts will keep the economy on track.
Following are the results of the Government's regular weekly bill auction:

HEADLINE: Microsoft Says Proposed Netscape Deal Supports Its Case

BYLINE: By JOEL BRINKLEY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23

 BODY:
The Microsoft Corporation argued in Federal court today that the proposed acquisition of the Netscape Communications Corporation by America Online seriously undermined the Government's antitrust suit against the software giant.
"From a legal standpoint, this proposed deal pulls the rug out from under the Government," William Neukom, Microsoft's senior vice president for legal affairs, said this morning on the courthouse steps. 
 The reasoning behind this assertion, Microsoft says, is that the proposed deal demonstrates that Netscape and the larger software industry are healthy and vibrant -- even with all of the illegal and anticompetitive practices charged in the Government's suit.
But David Boies, the Government's lead attorney, said all of that was irrelevant. "Whatever the deal ends up being -- if there ends up being a deal -- is not going to remove any of the obstacles that Microsoft has placed in the path of competition in this industry," he said.
 Michael Lacovara, a Microsoft lawyer who was questioning a Government witness, the economist Frederick R. Warren-Boulton, suggested to him during the trial today that the proposed acquisition undermined his argument that Microsoft seems headed toward obtaining a monopoly in Internet browser software to match the one it apparently holds in operating systems. After all, about 22 percent of Americans who use the Internet reach it through America Online. And at present America Online uses Microsoft's Web browser, Internet Explorer, as the service's default choice. In exchange for that, Microsoft places an America Online advertisement and Internet link in Windows 98.
Mr. Lacovara asked the witness whether, once America Online's service contract expires in January, "would you expect AOL to continue to distribute Microsoft software?" Yes, Mr. Warren-Boulton responded. "It is not at all clear to me that AOL's incentive to do this is changed by this proposed merger with Netscape." He noted that America Online officials had said their need to be among the on-line services featured in Windows forced them to accept Microsoft terms -- establishing Internet Explorer as the default choice.
Mr. Lacovara then asked him the question that lay under his entire cross-examination of the witness -- and Microsoft's larger assertion today about the proposed Netscape-America Online deal. "Surely this combination," he asked, 'tells you something about the nature of competition in the software industry?"
Mr. Warren-Boulton's answer was probably not the one Mr. Lacovara had been after.
"To the extent that this potential merger is the result of Microsoft's actions with these exclusive contracts and other actions," he said, "it is unfortunate to see the disappearance of a firm like Netscape, the brightest, newest star."
Mr. Warren-Boulton's purpose on the stand for the Government is to establish that Microsoft does have a monopoly in operating-system software; more than 90 percent of the world's computers use a Microsoft operating system. That is the foundation under most of the Government's case since Federal antitrust law forbids certain behavior by a monopolist that would be legal for a firm that faces healthy competition.
Through repeated, often circumlocutious questioning, Mr. Lacovara tried to make the case that Microsoft's overwhelming market share was ephemeral. The software industry is so vibrant and fast moving, he suggested, that Microsoft could be toppled from its position at any moment -- a point of view the company encourages among its employees.
On Friday and today Mr. Lacovara repeatedly pointed out that other companies are placing other operating systems on the market, and some software companies -- principally Microsoft's greatest rivals -- are writing software for these new systems. But Mr. Warren-Boulton argued that "the existence of these fringe competitors in the operating system market does not mean in any way that Microsoft does not have monopoly power."
This afternoon Mr. Lacovara made an issue of the success the Apple Computer Company is having selling its new iMac computer. He entered into evidence an Apple news release issued last month showing, among other things, that 12.5 percent of the people buying Apple's new iMac computer had previously owned a Windows machine. Apple computers use a different operating system, Mac-OS.

HEADLINE: CUNY Approves Stiffer Test Intended to Gauge Writing Ability

BYLINE: By KAREN W. ARENSON 

 BODY:
Adding yet another test to insure the English proficiency of graduates, the trustees of the City University of New York yesterday began requiring that students pass a new writing examination before they enter the third year of studies at senior colleges or transfer as upperclassmen from other colleges.
CUNY's community college students will also have to pass the new test to graduate. The test replaces the writing placement examination that the trustees imposed as a community college graduation requirement in May 1997. 
 The new test will apply to freshmen entering next fall. The proposal passed by a vote of 14 to 0, with the student trustee abstaining.
The test, developed with the help of a faculty committee and testing experts, is widely seen as an improvement over the current writing test, which was designed as a diagnostic tool for placing students in the appropriate writing courses. But some faculty members and students still dislike use of a single high-stakes examination to determine whether students can continue their studies.
The new exam was designed to measure skills needed in standard college course work. Students will have two hours to read a one- or two-page article and then write an essay that shows that they have understood what they read and that offers some criticism or analysis. Several questions will suggest questions to answer or themes to address in writing the essay.
In the placement test used now, students are asked to write a short essay in response to two open-ended questions on topics like "Is America still a land of opportunity?" or "Do celebrities make good role models?"
Some trustees expressed reservations about adopting the test before it has been subjected to a careful pilot review next spring. But Anne A. Paolucci, CUNY's chairwoman, said that it was important to approve the test now "to give us the momentum."
"We need this incentive of having voted on it to go ahead properly," she said, stressing that the board could still amend the testing process after the pilot test was completed.
Some critical details have not yet been decided, including how many times students will be allowed to take the test or what will happen to those who fail it. But on a board where the debate sometimes turns confrontational, most of the discussion yesterday was cordial.
The only vocal opposition came from a small group of student and faculty protesters, corralled inside police barriers across from CUNY's East 80th Street building. The protesters waved large turkey placards with trustees' faces on them and the words "Board of Turkeys."
One protester, Blandon Casenave, a Hunter College senior in economics and political science, called the new test a trap "designed to keep people from having having access to the senior colleges."
The examination will be pilot-tested next spring. In a preliminary trial on 2,000 students in freshmen English courses last spring, just under a quarter failed it. Students are likely to be further along in their studies when they take the new test.
About 68 percent of freshmen failed the current writing placement test when they entered CUNY last year.
Faculty members expressed mixed feelings about the new examination. Although many see it as a clear advance over the current writing examination, others are concerned that it could interfere with students' ability to stay in school.
"It is very unfair to impose this without giving the students the support and teaching they need," said Lawrence Rushing, a psychology professor at La Guardia Community College.
Mizanoor Biswas, the student trustee, expressed similar concerns yesterday, saying he would be more comfortable voting after he saw the results of the pilot test next spring. "As much as I agree this is a better test," he said, "I see a need for more money for English departments."
Another concern is that students who are members of racial minorities performed less well on the preliminary pilot test last spring than their white classmates. Roughly a quarter of the Hispanic, Asian and black students failed the test, compared to only 14 percent of the white students. Students from homes where English was not the only language spoken also did somewhat less well than their classmates.
The old writing examination will continue to be used as one of the three CUNY placement tests (along with tests in mathematics and reading) that determine whether students need remedial help when they enter the university. Under a policy adopted last May, students must also pass all of those tests before they will be allowed to enter the four-year colleges. That policy was to be phased in beginning next fall, but is on hold pending the outcome of a court suit over whether the trustees adhered to the state's open meetings law when they passed it.
CUNY officials said that other state university systems, including those in California, Texas and Florida, used a common proficiency exam or would soon require one.

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
Imbalance In Baseball Costs George

BYLINE: By HARVEY ARATON 

 BODY:
HOW can the New York Yankees not be worth, say, four times as much as the new Cleveland Browns? The answer to a question I continue to hear and have wondered about myself is found in a subtext to the widely speculated sale of George Steinbrenner's team.
That is, the Boss's effort to fortify the middle of his lineup, and the meager number of teams with enough money to contest him. 
 Despite the champion Yankees and Mark McGwire and Sammy Sosa and retro ball parks and a basketball lockout, baseball is flirting dangerously with the collapse of competitive balance. This calamity-in-waiting obviously reflects in the range of the reported sales prices of Steinbrenner's biggest deal ever, one that is said to be in the late innings, with Cablevision's monopoly money closer, Charles F. Dolan, warming up.
The reported low figure is $550 million, and the high one is $1 billion, with the final price likely in between. I'm not implying that Steinbrenner, a la Kenny Anderson, might ever have to sell one of his cars for some pocket change, for the deal ultimately will be an American record. But what, then, are we to make of these figures relative to Rupert Murdoch's $1 billion bid for the Manchester United soccer team and Al Lerner's $530 million fee for that expansion Cleveland football team not yet in possession of a single shoulder pad?
Millions of New Yorkers have been conditioned -- by Steinbrenner, among others -- to believe that no property in the sports universe could compare to a storied franchise whose broadcast rights netted almost $500 million more than a decade ago, and comes with its own collection of monuments to itself. Now a soccer team is worth more, and a shell of a small-market football franchise almost as much?
Believe it, said Andrew Zimbalist, a professor of economics at Smith College who has written extensively on the industry and claims the legacy of the Babe and Joe D. don't carry as much market weight as a sound revenue-sharing plan.
"That's like saying Chrysler, because of its history, should sell for more money than Microsoft," Zimbalist said. "The fact is, football is golden, with a massive television contract and labor peace. Baseball is still in trouble because you have five or six teams bidding for all the best players."
Think about it. As this free-agent season has evolved, when was the last time anyone uttered the words Kansas City Royals? There are just too many sad welfare cases that have, as the major league baseball executive Sandy Alderson told Murray Chass in Sunday's New York Times, practically "given up."
Alderson used to run one of them, the Oakland A's, which reminds me of a weekday afternoon game in Oakland that I took my family to last July. The crowd was a few thousand, half of them camp kids on 99 cents admission. After the game, in the souvenir shop, my sons reached for batting helmets under a sign that read: $5, 50 percent off.
At the counter, I paid with a $10 bill, and received $5 change. I held up a helmet in each hand. "Two-fifty apiece," the guy said.
When I asked how he could sell merchandise that cheap, he said: "Buddy, you see today's crowd? It's only getting worse." Maybe we do have a distorted view of the game back home, I thought. Maybe that helps explain those shrinking World Series ratings, Yanks or no Yanks.
As the media corporations dig into their pockets, the gulf between rich and poor is only widening. Nobody, least of all Commissioner Bud Selig, will acknowledge that Murdoch, owner of the Dodgers and almost every television signal, has become baseball's de facto czar. As such, he most likely will not even have his hopelessly conflicted partnership with Dolan challenged, if and when the Yankees' sale is concluded.
"Without knowing anything about the Yankees' books, I am surprised that the sales price wouldn't be more in a media market like that," said Tom Murdo, the manufacturer of children's products who unsuccessfully bid for the Browns. "In my opinion, the Browns are not worth $530 million, but football is viewed as a better industry than baseball."
Maybe the Yankees would be worth more if Steinbrenner waited until after the city builds him luxury boxes. Or perhaps he senses that baseball, with no meaningful global upside, like Michael Jordan and Manchester United, has been artificially pumped up by the home run derby. Whatever the deal, Steinbrenner will become richer than ever, but must live on with one nagging thought.
After all these years, he still isn't that much bigger than Cleveland, where he cut his teeth on a silver spoon.

HEADLINE: Long a Leader, U.S. Now Lags In High School Graduate Rate

BYLINE: By ETHAN BRONNER 

 BODY:
A major new international study shows that American high school graduation rates, for generations the highest in the world, have slipped below those of most industrialized countries.
The report, released yesterday by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development in Paris, which helps coordinate policy for 29 of the richest countries, suggests that the changing picture is less a matter of American backsliding than of substantial recent progress by other nations. 
 For example, in 1990, the average number of years an American 5-year-old was expected to attend school or college was the world's highest, 16.3. In 1996, the latest year for which data were available, the American score was 16.8, but 11 other countries, including Canada, Spain and Finland, had surpassed that number.
In addition, the report found that the United States devoted a smaller percentage of its national income to teacher salaries than other countries.
The United States remains on top in the percentage of students who enter college, but a pattern similar to high school graduation rates is emerging.
"Entry rates to college education in the U.S. are still the highest in the O.E.C.D. but that is likely to change soon," said Andreas Schleicher, principal administrator at the organization and one of the study's authors. "While enrollments in the United States remained relatively stable between 1990 and 1996, they increased by more than 25 percent in 16 O.E.C.D. countries."
He added that the United States also had one of the highest university dropout rates in the industrialized world -- 37 percent.
The report was the fifth such study issued by the organization since 1991, when it started examining educational trends. Mr. Schleicher said that over the last three years the report has been the organization's best-selling publication.
The report offers far more data than analysis, but it suggests that growing emphasis in other countries on high school graduation is a result of "the desire of employers to have better skilled workers and, hence, from individuals who see that educational qualifications improve their life chances."
Mr. Schleicher said the other nations in his organization had placed enormous emphasis on improving access to education, bringing them in line with and surpassing American achievements.
The shifting balance is likely to cause concern in the United States, because the quality of American education has been the focus of growing debate for 10 to 15 years.
"I think we should be quite alarmed by this," said Gerald Graff, professor of English and education at the University of Chicago, who is writing a book on what he considers the dangerous gap between the thinking classes in America and the rest of the society. "We've never fully committed ourselves to the democratic idea of education. There is a kind of silent bargain between schools and many of its students that says, 'We'll leave you alone if you just sit there and don't bother us.' "
Earlier this year, the results of a mathematics and science test for 12th graders in many countries showed students in the United States to be among the least knowledgeable. Earlier tests showed that the lowest 25 percent of 8th graders in Japan and South Korea to outperform the average American student.
Education was widely cited by voters as their top concern in this month's state and Federal elections. Candidates of both major parties vowing increased spending on teacher training and school improvement.
Education has risen and fallen as a political issue for generations. The Soviet Union's launching of the Sputnik satellite in 1957 spurred schools in the United States to require more math and science courses.
The issue most recently gained a high profile in 1983 with the publication by the U.S. Education Department of an alarming report on American education entitled "A Nation at Risk" which said that if a foreign power had imposed such a low level of education on the United States, it would rightfully have been perceived as having engaged in an act of war.
In the years since, there have been numerous efforts to improve the nation's schools, from alternatives to public education like charter schools and voucher plans to projects to improve teacher quality, widely perceived as the system's Achilles' heel. Some states are now testing student teachers more rigorously and offering signing bonuses and student loan forgiveness to encourage better candidates to enter the profession.
Many states are also instituting tests at various stages to insure that students do not graduate without basic skills and knowledge.
Yesterday's report shows that Americans between the ages of 55 and 64, who graduated high school some 40 years ago, had a graduation rate of 77 percent, the highest of those surveyed. Among those ages 24 to 34, the United States' rate slipped to eighth position. Today's graduation rates, with the United States at 72 percent, place it second to last in the 29-nation group, above Mexico.
It seems unlikely that the shift reflects higher standards for graduation in the United States because comparisons of adult literacy rates in the study show Americans to be among the industrialized world's least literate populations.
According to the report, the United States' expenditure per pupil is still among the highest in the group at all levels of education. It stands out in the way it has brought the private sector into college and university education, leading the way, according to Mr. Schleicher, in a growing international trend.
"Across the O.E.C.D., students in both public and private colleges are being asked to pay more for their education," he said. "Unlike in the United States, however, this spending has, in many countries, supplemented rather than displaced public spending on education."
But while the United States spends a great deal on education in absolute terms, its expenditure is about average as a percentage of gross domestic product. Moreover, teacher pay viewed through the same lens shows the United States to be among the lowest, while demands on teacher time in class are among the highest.
An experienced high school teacher in the United States earns 1.2 times the nation's gross domestic product per capita. Only the Czech Republic, Hungary and Norway pay their high school teachers less when measured as a percentage of gross domestic product. In Germany, Ireland, South Korea and Switzerland, among others, teachers earn twice or more of the per capita G.D.P.
Moreover, the average teacher salary in this country is significantly below that of other university graduates; in many other countries, like Australia, France and Britain, it is above it.
The amount of time a typical middle school teacher in the United States spends in front of a classroom per year is 964 hours, among the highest in the report.
The report adds that Americans cannot comfort themselves by thinking that theirs is a society of social mobility. It finds that children whose parents completed college are more than three times as likely to become college graduates as children whose parents did not complete high school. Moreover, the achievement gap between the well-off children of the well-educated and others is above the average for the 29 industrialized nations.

HEADLINE: Et Tu, New Jersey Nets?;
Meadowlands Sports Complex Faces Franchise Unrest

BYLINE: By DAVID KOCIENIEWSKI 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Nov. 23

 BODY:
For generations, New Jersey officials have excelled at peddling their proximity to Manhattan, using the promise of tax abatements, new buildings and ample parking to lure New York businesses and sports franchises west of the Hudson.
Already this year New Jersey has bid aggressively, and unsuccessfully, to bring the New York Stock Exchange to Jersey City. Members of Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's administration have quietly tried to lure George M. Steinbrenner 3d and the New York Yankees to the Meadowlands complex in East Rutherford, N.J. 
 So imagine the consternation in the state capital when a group of Newark investors set their sights this summer on a new trophy: the Nets basketball team.
The New Jersey Nets.
The Nets' new owners, headed by Raymond G. Chambers, a philanthropist, want to move the team 14 miles south, from the Meadowlands to Newark. They are lobbying the state to help spur Newark's redevelopment efforts by building a downtown arena on a vacant parcel of land a few blocks from the new New Jersey Performing Arts Center.
The Nets' proposal is only one of many efforts, both in the region and beyond, by team owners trying to obtain new, more lucrative stadium deals. A half-dozen National Football League teams have moved into new quarters in recent years, and last week the Governor of Connecticut announced a deal to build a $350 million stadium to lure the New England Patriots to Hartford from Foxboro, Mass.
In addition, the Nets' plan also comes at a time when the New Jersey Devils' owner, John McMullen, is asking the state to build a hockey arena in Hoboken, placing Mrs. Whitman in the unpleasant position of scrambling to placate existing franchises rather than wooing new ones.
Although the exact details of the plans will be determined during months of negotiations, it seems certain that the Whitman administration will be forced to pay hundreds of millions of dollars to build a new stadium, new roads and rail connections or all three. The Devils' owner says he is unhappy with the team's present site, Continental Airlines Arena, because it isn't accessible by train and has far fewer luxury boxes than arenas housing other National Hockey League franchises.
The Nets' new owners say they want to aid the rehabilitation of downtown Newark and, in the words of the team president, Michael Rowe, "to be part of an urban community where we can make a real difference with kids who live there."
Even the MetroStars soccer team is contemplating leaving the Meadowlands because its players prefer a natural grass field and Giants Stadium is equipped with artificial turf.
The prospect of the Nets' move also raises troubling questions about the future of the Meadowlands, an enormously successful sports complex that coaxed the Jets and Giants football teams out of New York City and helped New Jersey land its own major league hockey, basketball and soccer franchises.
"It's a lot more fun to play offense than defense," said Raymond H. Bateman, chairman of the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority, which operates the Meadowlands.
In New York City Hall, where Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has frequently criticized New Jersey for snatching New York's businesses, some officials find poetic justice in watching the poachers become the poached. During Mr. Giuliani's tenure, New Jersey successfully sued for the rights to 90 percent of Ellis Island and forced New York City to pay hundreds of millions of dollars in tax breaks and subsidies to retain the stock exchange, Conde Nast, Avon, General Motors and other major businesses.
And the idea of moving the Nets to Newark also resonates with Mr. Giuliani's desire to build a baseball stadium for the Yankees on the West Side of Manhattan. "This is another indication that the hot place to be is in an urban center," said Cristyne F. Lategano, Mr. Giuliani's director of communications. "If you look at the experiments taking place with baseball stadia moving to the center of cities like Baltimore and Cleveland, it's not at all surprising."
Members of the Whitman administration say the situation, though complex, is hardly a worst-case scenario.
"If people over in New York take comfort in this, we're happy for them," said Peter McDonough, Mrs. Whitman's director of communications. "We've got five pro sports teams playing here and the good news is that none of them are considering moving out of New Jersey."
In some respects, the housing complaints of the Nets and the Devils would not exist without the success of the Meadowlands. Thirty years ago, the current site of the complex was a desolate stretch of swamp; part wetland, part garbage dump.
But in the early 1970's, Gov. William T. Cahill saw the expanse of vacant land, with its easy access to New York City, as a chance to put the state into the entertainment world's big leagues, by luring the Yankees to suburbia. When Mayor John V. Lindsay of New York agreed to overhaul Yankee Stadium, the team decided to stay put. So New Jersey officials convinced the Giants' owner, Wellington Mara, whose team shared Yankee Stadium at the time, that he need not be a second-class tenant, and the Meadowlands won its first franchise.
New York officials nearly managed to scuttle the plan by undermining support for the bonds New Jersey issued to finance the project, but by 1976 both the football stadium and a nearby race track were operating.
In the heady early days, after New Jersey wooed the Jets and made a bid for the Rangers, the Sports and Exposition Authority's executive director, Robert E. Mulcahy 3d, said he once bumped into Gov. Hugh L. Carey of New York in an elevator and was treated as if he were the second coming of Walter O'Malley, the man who moved the Brooklyn Dodgers to Los Angeles.
"He asked me, 'Mulcahy, what are you going to steal next?' " said Mr. Mulcahy, now the athletic director of Rutgers University. "I told him, 'Governor, whatever I can get my hands on.' "
Today, the 750-acre complex, complete with a race track, outdoor stadium and indoor arena, is one of the busiest sports centers in the nation, with revenues near $150 million a year. From 1994 to 1996, it enjoyed its most impressive run of big-name events, as host to the World Cup soccer championships, dozens of outdoor concerts, a visit by Pope John Paul II, the Devils' Stanley Cup Championship and college basketball's Final Four tournament.
But competition for sports franchises has become so fierce, and the economics of stadium-building so convoluted, that a modern arena doesn't necessarily placate franchise owners for long.
Continental Arena, which opened in 1981, is mechanically sound, has good sight lines and is considered a pleasant stadium by most spectators. But Mr. McMullen, the Devils' owner, has complained for years that it does not have enough luxury boxes and corporate suites, which generate huge profits for the franchise. When the Devils made their successful Stanley Cup run in 1995, Mr. McMullen seized the moment to threaten a move to Tennessee, saying that the Meadowlands' luxury box gap had made it financially impossible for the Devils to compete with teams housed in newer centers.
Mrs. Whitman gave Mr. McMullen $5 million a year in concessions and persuaded him to sign a lease until the 2006-7 season. He has since demanded that the state help pay for a new center, to be built over an abandoned rail yard in Hoboken, a proposal many experts believe is prohibitively expensive.
State officials had hoped to persuade both the Devils and the Nets to stay at the Meadowlands by upgrading the arena, and hired an architectural firm this year to study the feasibility of renovating or replacing Continental Arena at its current East Rutherford site. The firm, which will release its preliminary findings next month, is expected to recommend razing the existing building and replacing it with a new 20,000-seat arena packed with restaurants, sports bars, movie theaters, a shopping concourse and an unspecified number of luxury boxes.
But whatever the Meadowlands proposal recommends, it cannot meet one of the primary concerns of Mr. Chambers, the leader of the Nets' new owners -- helping to revitalize Newark.
Mr. Chambers, who owns 19 percent of the team, shuns publicity and declined to be interviewed. But others familiar with his plans say he envisions a new downtown arena as a cornerstone in Newark's renaissance. State Senator Richard J. Codey, an Essex County Democrat who supports the project, said private developers had agreed to build a mall near the downtown site to help develop a shopping district and night life in Newark.
"What I want to do is turn this into a public policy issue," said Mr. Codey, the Senate minority leader. "We've already built the Meadowlands and turned that area of the state around. Why not do the same thing for Newark?"
Although Mrs. Whitman has indicated in the past that she would prefer to rebuild the Meadowlands arena, her aides privately concede that Mr. Chambers' involvement alters the equation.
If the Devils, or the MetroStars soccer team, can be persuaded to relocate to Newark, the state will face additional pressure to build a downtown stadium. Even if the Nets decide to go it alone, Mr. Chambers, who helped finance the Newark Performing Arts Center, has the financial clout to finance a downtown arena without the state's help.
"There's a lot of jockeying going on, between the teams, between the Meadowlands and the teams," Mr. McDonough said. "The Governor's position is just let it all play out and make a decision in the end."
State Senator Franz S. Leichter of New York, a frequent critic of government tax abatements, said it would be foolhardy for New Yorkers to gloat.
"If anything, this will probably accelerate the problem," Mr. Leichter said. "If the Meadowlands loses the Nets, they'll say: 'We have to replace them! Let's go get the Knicks!' "

And the hockey Devils are threatening to move to Hoboken. The Meadowlands complex, until recently a prime lurer of teams, now finds itself on the other end. (Michelle V. Agins/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
NFO WORLDWIDE BUYS GERMAN MARKET RESEARCH COMPANY

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
NFO Worldwide Inc., the largest custom market research company in the United States, bought a closely held German company, Infratest Burke, for $120 million in cash. The transaction will create the world's sixth-largest market research firm. NFO, based in Greenwich, Conn., also assumed $28 million in Infratest debt and will pay $3 million more in the next two and a half years for Infratest, which has annual sales of about $165 million. NFO said in October that it planned to expand into international markets. The combined company will operate in 31 countries and have more than 13,000 full- and part-time employees. Shares of NFO, which changed its name from NFO Research last month, rose $1, to $8.25, on the New York Stock Exchange.

Police Say Men Died In a Murder-Suicide

DATELINE: CLAYTON

 BODY:
A man who had been barred from contacting his estranged wife went to her house here Sunday night and used a shotgun to kill her male companion and himself, law enforcement officials said yesterday.
The husband, Michael A. Myers, 23, shot the man, Gary Dahl, 36, of Clayton, about 8:45 P.M. as Mr. Dahl baby-sat for the Myerses' 4-year-old son, said Debbie Romano, a spokeswoman for the Gloucester County Prosecutor's office. She said the boy was in the basement at the time and was not hurt, and his mother was not at home. 
 Chief Frank Winters of the Clayton police said a restraining order was issued on Aug. 18 after a series of harassing phone calls and other nonviolent incidents. He said Mr. Myers, who was unemployed and had no known address, called the house from a cellular phone several times on the day of the shootings, once while an officer was present and got on the phone to warn him to stop.
Chief Winters said Mr. Myers may have been watching the house and waiting for the police and his wife to leave.

HEADLINE: Some Depressions Aren't So Bad

BYLINE: By Niall Ferguson; Niall Ferguson is the author of "The House of Rothschild."

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
A s the Dow Jones industrial average surged yesterday past the peak it reached last July, I was reminded of the English historian A. J. P. Taylor's remark that the only thing men learn from history is how to make new mistakes. Nothing demonstrates how easy it is to draw the wrong lessons from the past than the overheated talk of a second Great Depression following the short-lived drop in the stock market last summer.
When people refer to the Depression they obviously mean the catastrophic slump that followed the Wall Street crash of Oct. 24, 1929. The scars from that time run so deep that some economists mention it nearly every time the Dow Jones industrial average suffers a big one-day slide. 
 In July and August, when the Dow plunged by nearly 2,000 points, people wondered if Alan Greenspan would see his hard-won reputation as the world's most successful central banker evaporate in one final swoon. Not this time.
Maybe, however, we're looking at the wrong historical precedent. For there is another. It predates 1929, and it is much less scary.
The Great Depression of the 1930's was, in fact, the second such worldwide period of deflation. The first began in the 1870's and did not end until the mid-1890's.
What relevance does the depression of more than 100 years ago have in 1998? In many ways the world today is more like that of the late 19th century than it is like the world between the wars. The global economy in the 1920's and 1930's was hampered by restrictions on trade and on the movement of capital, as well as by numerous structural problems that originated in the huge disruption created by World War I.
By contrast, the world economy in 1873 was characterized by unprecedentedly free trade, thanks to the fashion for laissez-faire economics pioneered by Britain.
Huge infusions of capital were pumped into the world economy as investors sought higher returns in the late 19th century's emerging markets, notably Russia and Latin America. In some ways North America was an emerging market, too.
In those days, the world's financial center was London, with Paris in second place. Today, of course, New York is the hub, even if the Japanese have long been the world's biggest overseas net lenders. Capital movements are managed (if that is not too flattering a term) by giant companies like Merrill Lynch in partnership with smaller hedge funds. In the 1870's the international economy's No. 1 market maker was the House of Rothschild, a vast multinational investment bank that continued to be run, as it had been since the 1790's, as a family business.
The late 1860's and early 1870's were a boom time for the Rothschilds and their lesser imitators. The United States, emerging from the wreckage of the Civil War, was forging ahead with its railway network. German unification was followed by a boom east of the Rhine (rather as German reunification was after 1989).
In Central and Eastern Europe, the economy of the once stagnant Hapsburg Empire in Austria-Hungary began at last to grow. In Russia, the reforms of Czar Alexander II (beginning with the emancipation of the serfs) were ushering in rapid industrialization, financed mainly by foreign investors. Other countries eager for outside capital included Argentina and Brazil. And in the East, British imperialism was beginning to open up the potentially vast Chinese economy.
As in our own day, a key to the global boom was a revolution in communications. For the Victorians, it consisted of railways, steamships and the telegraph. Speeds for international communication were reduced from months to hours.
The Great Depression began on May 8, 1873, with a big slump on the Vienna stock market. The contagion soon spread to London. Central banks cut their base interest rates (the Bank of England's went from 9 percent in 1873 to 2 percent two years later), but to no avail.
The important point about the first Great Depression is that it was primarily a deflationary phenomenon. From 1873 to 1895, British prices fell by 44 percent. This happened more or less everywhere. By contrast (and this is the big difference between the 1880's and the 1930's), production did not fall substantially, and unemployment remained comparatively low.
This has profound implications for our own day. Commodity prices have fallen sharply -- down 18 percent in the past year. But Americans and Europeans are feeling more gain than pain.
Economists and central bankers tend to take it for granted that deflation is a bad thing, with falling output and unemployment its necessary accompaniment. As the case of Japan illustrates, there is some truth in this: indeed, it can be a self-fulfilling trend, in that pessimism breeds reluctance to invest. But the experience of the late 19th century suggests that deflation need not invariably be associated with universal economic misery.
Of course, there were losers then. In the United States, the Populists, a movement that began with disgruntled farmers, attributed the low prices they were getting to a conspiracy of bankers led by the Rothschilds.
The Populists blamed the United States' adoption of the British gold standard system of fixed exchange rates for the economic disruption. What was needed was an infusion of money -- more silver and more paper dollars -- to create mild inflation.
Similar pleas can be heard today, in different circumstances. The economist Paul Krugman has urged Japan to "print money like crazy" to revive its economy -- a remedy that the Populists favored long before Keynes. Other losers (including heavy industry) argued for protectionist tariffs or sought refuge in price-fixing cartels.
If nothing else, the Populists were right about the importance of the international monetary system as a transmission belt for financial crises.
Banking crises recurred throughout the period, notably the Barings bank crisis in London in 1890 (which prompted a bailout financed by the Rothschilds that was much like the recent private-sector rescue of the Long-Term Capital Management hedge fund).
But the key point is that not everyone lost as a result of deflation in the 1870's and 1880's. Stock speculators and commodity producers certainly suffered. But poorer consumers -- that is, most people -- clearly benefited from cheaper prices for food and other essentials. And falling prices did not discourage businessmen like the Rothschilds or John D. Rockefeller Sr. from investing; in fact, it was precisely the prospect of ever cheaper fuel that encouraged both to invest millions in the nascent oil industry.
So here, for those who want a new lesson from history, is the bad news: yes, another Great Depression is possible. In Japan it may have already begun, though so far central bankers elsewhere are managing to fend off serious deflation by cutting interest rates. (This time there's no gold standard to worry about.) The good news is that, if a depression comes, it will be a lot more like the price-cutting one of 1873 to 1895 than the economic catastrophe of the 1930's.

HEADLINE: Schroder's Morning After: Winning the Vote Was the Easy Part

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN 

DATELINE: BERLIN, Nov. 24

 BODY:
Less than a month after he swept into office with a ready smile and talk of a "new middle" that would revitalize Germany, Chancellor Gerhard Schroder has lost much of the momentum and good will that propelled his ascent.
Sniped at by state premiers who wield much power in Germany's decentralized system, criticized by his Green coalition partners, attacked by leading businessmen and buffeted within his own Social Democratic Party, Mr. Schroder has appeared unable to impose his stamp on the Government. 
 "There is no need to panic," Peter Struck, the leader of the Social Democratic Party in Parliament, said today, but the admonition itself clearly reflected mounting concern. Heide Ruhle, the party manager of the environmentalist Greens, declared that Germany "cannot be governed by the troops of chaos."
At a time when German companies are on a self-confident buying spree in the United States -- Deutsche Bank's impending purchase of Banker's Trust follows Daimler's acquisition of Chrysler and Bertelsmann's absorption of Random House -- this political uncertainty may appear out of character.
But the reality of Germany today is a streamlined and aggressive corporate sector, acutely aware of the challenges of the global economy, alongside an uncertain social and political model that Mr. Schroder has vowed to galvanize.
In part, Mr. Schroder's difficulties stem from teething problems that are inevitable given the Social Democrats' 16-year absence from power, and from the fact that a coalition government with the Greens was widely regarded as unlikely before the September elections, so few preparations for it were made.
"They were not prepared at all, nothing was prepared, and then the program was put together in haste," said Claus Leggewie, a sociologist close to the Government. "It does look kind of amateurish."
But at a deeper level, Mr. Schroder seems to be suffering from the very ambiguities of his campaign. While his ability to appear both as an energetic modernizer and a traditional Social Democrat sensitive to workers' concerns was effective at election rallies, it seems to be proving too wide a stretch for government.
Tensions in the Social Democratic Party burst into the open with the recent publication of a blunt letter to Mr. Schroder from Wolfgang Clement, the Social Democratic Premier of North Rhine-Westphalia state, which has a huge economy itself with a population larger than that of the Netherlands.
Mr. Clement said the tax reforms proposed by the Government were inadequate and would do nothing to reduce unemployment, now running at more than 10 percent. He suggested slashing the corporate income tax level to below 30 percent from more than 40 percent, and lowering top tax rates for individuals.
He also denounced Government plans to close tax loopholes for corporations and raise energy taxes, saying the changes would cost businesses about $17.8 billion. The thrust of his argument, which is also that of big business, was that only a deregulation of Germany's economy will spur corporations to create jobs.
The letter revealed the extent of the chasm between reformist Social Democrats like Mr. Clement and Finance Minister Oskar Lafontaine, who has focused more on the widening gap between rich and poor in Germany, the need to spur growth through cutting interest rates, and the possibilities of creating employment through a state-sponsored "alliance for jobs" bringing together labor unions and industry leaders.
For the moment, Mr. Schroder, whose essential political talent is that of a very effective communicator at once polished and unruffled, has appeared to want to remain above the fray.
This policy of aloofness may spare him the worst of the vitriol flying between the wings of his party, but at some point it appears inevitable that the Chancellor will have to intervene more forcefully or face growing criticism for indecisiveness.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Canadians Raise Concerns About Mexican Labor Law

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA 

DATELINE: TORONTO, Nov. 24

 BODY:
Mexican officials have acknowledged that their labor laws do not adequately protect the rights of Mexican workers, according to documents obtained by Canadian union officials who have filed a complaint against Mexico under the North American Free Trade Agreement.
The Canadian complaint involves conditions at an automobile brake plant outside Mexico City that is owned by the Dana Corporation of Toledo, Ohio, and follows a similar action taken in the United States earlier this year. 
 If both complaints determine that Mexico did not adequately enforce its labor laws, it could lead to the first sanction applied since Nafta went into effect in January 1994.
The Canadian office of the United Steelworkers of America and 40 labor and human rights organizations from Canada, Mexico and the United States contend that workers at the plant were intimidated and in some cases beaten when they tried to switch unions in 1997.
According to the complaint, workers at the brake plant, which operates under the name Itapsa, wanted to organize an independent union because wages were stuck at $5 a day and there were dangerous levels of asbestos dust.
The existing union, the Confederation of Mexican Workers, has strong links to the Government and reportedly ignored worker complaints. On Sept. 9, 1997, Itapsa workers voted on switching to an independent union, but they said they did so in the presence of outsiders carrying sticks and pipes. They were also forced to declare their vote at an open meeting in front of plant supervisors.
Under the labor side agreement, each country in the accord has established an administrative office to receive such complaints.
In April, the Canadian office received the complaint about the union vote and the safety conditions at the Itapsa plant. In September, the head of the Canadian office, May Morpaw, traveled to Mexico to meet with her counterpart, Rafael Aranda, and officials from the Mexican Labor Department.
In the notes of the meeting, which were obtained by the steelworkers union, Mexican labor officials acknowledged that union representation elections were usually not conducted in secret, even though workers could be dismissed if they voted for the losing union.
The Mexican officials also said they were not concerned that the lack of secrecy had made it inevitable that employers would know how a worker had voted. The Mexican officials said such elections were free and open, but they could not guarantee that coercion did not occur outside the voting site, according to the document.
In response to calls over several days seeking comment, the Mexican Labor Department sent a one-page summary of the complaint by fax but did not elaborate on the contents of Ms. Morpaw's notes.
The administrative office in the United States issued a report in July supporting most of the accusations in the complaint about Itapsa filed there. The office sent the complaint to the next stage in the regulatory process, which is direct consultations among the labor ministers of the three countries.
Ms. Morpaw of the Canadian office said a vote on whether to make a similar reference was scheduled for early December.
The accusations concerning free association for union members can only be taken up in talks among the labor ministers. But if two of the three labor ministers are sufficiently convinced that asbestos levels prove worker safety laws were not enforced at the plants, the issue could result in the first labor sanctions against Mexico.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
F.C.C. Says Sprint and Telmex Overcharged on Some Rates

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24

 BODY:
The Federal Government said today that it had received significant evidence that a joint venture created by the Sprint Corporation and Telefonos de Mexico, or Telmex, had committed anticompetitive practices in the long-distance market.
As a result, the Federal Communications Commission rejected the venture's proposed rates that are charged to other long-distance carriers. The agency also gave the venture 30 days to explain why officials should not review its long-distance license. 
 "U.S. consumers have to pay much more than they should to reach friends and relatives in Mexico," said William E. Kennard, the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission. "The carriers have not moved quickly enough to bring these rates down and ensure meaningful competition."
Mr. Kennard said that the high rates affected "the most vulnerable consumers," recent Hispanic immigrants who used the service to talk with friends and relatives back home.
Sprint officials said that the joint venture had been caught in a struggle between American and Mexican authorities, and that the company's pricing had not been unreasonable.
"We're disappointed by today's development," the company said in a statement. "The Telmex-Sprint Communications joint venture is in the marketplace today, enjoying initial success because it provides a service that Hispanic and other consumers want and need. We are confident that neither any U.S. carrier nor the public interest has been hurt by TSC's entry into the U.S. market."
Gary Epstein, a lawyer in Washington representing Telmex, said the venture had met all of the conditions of the license and that the company would dispute the allegations.
The joint venture's license was approved three months ago over the objections of the two biggest long- distance carriers in the United States, the AT&T Corporation and MCI Worldcom Inc. The high volume of calls between the two countries has generated some $700 million last year in payments to Telmex, far and away the largest payment overseas by American carriers.
In granting the license, regulators had imposed a list of conditions intended to keep the marketplace competitive. Officials said today that those conditions had not been met, and they took action following a new round of complaints by AT&T and MCI that the joint venture remained fundamentally anticompetitive.
At the heart of the today's action are the rules and fees governing the so-called settlement rate, the fees that phone companies make to each other to complete calls. Settlement rates have historically been set well above the cost of completing a call, particularly in countries with less- developed economies or powerful state-owned telephone monopolies.
Officials said that any reduction in the rates would be passed on to consumers in the form of lower telephone bills.
Telmex had promised to lower the settlement rate to 19 cents a minute by the beginning of the year 2000. The commission approved the 19- cent rate but rejected the company's interim rates of 37.5 cents for 1998 and 34.5 cents for 1999.
The agency also described a variety of other anticompetitive practices, such as a 58 percent surcharge levied by Telmex for international calls made to Mexico.
While officials said that the proceeding initiated today might not lead to the revocation of the venture's license, they expected it would encourage significant changes that would open the market to competitors of the Sprint-Telmex venture.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Concerns on Profit Outlook Help Deflate the Dow a Bit

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Stocks fell yesterday on concern that the euphoria that sent the Dow Jones industrial average up 21 percent in six weeks was unjustified by the outlook for corporate profits.
"Earnings expectations still aren't good enough for the run-up that happened" on Monday, said Cummins Catherwood, who helps manage $570 million at Rutherwood, Brown & Catherwood Inc. in Philadelphia. "Cooler heads are prevailing." 
 The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 73.12, or 0.8 percent, to 9,301.15, with American Express leading the decline. The Standard & Poor's 500 Index fell 5.22, or 0.4 percent, to 1,182.99. The Nasdaq Composite index lost 11.54, or 0.6 percent, to 1,965.88. American Express fell after an analyst downgraded the financial services company, saying that its profits will suffer as slowing worldwide economic growth reduces consumer spending.
The financial services company exemplifies the market's slump and quick recovery since mid-July. It sank as much as 41 percent, then jumped 50 percent from Oct. 8 through Monday. Yesterday, it fell 4 9/16, to 104 3/8, after Gary Gordon, a Paine Webber analyst, said the company's profit could be hurt by weaker consumer spending as economies in Asia, Latin America and the United States falter. The stock is trading at 22 times estimated 1998 earnings. Both the Dow industrials and the S.& P. 500 rose to all-time highs before retreating. The Dow industrials touched 9,457.95, while the S.& P. climbed as high as 1,191.30. The Dow average rose 214.72, to a record 9,374.27 on Monday, one of its quickest recoveries from a bear market since World War II.
After such a quick rally, "you ask whether earnings justify" prices, said Susan Flischel, the chief investment officer at the Cincinnati-based Countrywide Investments, which oversees $1 billion.
America Online, the No. 1 on-line service, rose 2 1/8, to 91 3/8, after it agreed to buy Netscape Communications for $4.2 billion, or $40.16 a share. Netscape fell 2 1/16, to 39 7/8.
The S.& P. 500 is priced at about 22 times the expected operating earnings per share for the coming four quarters, according to a survey of industry analysts by the First Call Corporation. The only time it has been higher in the last 50 years was in the first and second quarters of this year, when it reached 23 times earnings, said Chuck Hill, director of research at First Call.
Market strategists and economists, who typically take a more conservative view of profit growth than industry analysts, expect growth of 4.1 percent for the S.& P. 500, according to First Call.
Corporate profits faltered in the third quarter, putting in the weakest annual performance in almost a decade, the Government said. For the fourth quarter, analysts expect companies in the S.& P. 500 to post year-over-year operating earnings growth of 6.3 percent. At the beginning of the quarter, the forecast was for profits to grow 9.1 percent.
"I think people may begin to realize that valuations are a little out of range here," James Pizzo, a senior portfolio strategist with CIBC Oppenheimer & Company, said.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Bond Prices Climb Again
 By Bloomberg News
 Bonds rose for a fourth time in five days yesterday amid optimism for subdued inflation, increasing the appeal of Government securities.
The 30-year Treasury bond rose 26/32, to 100 24/32. Its yield fell 5 basis points, to 5.20 percent. Yields on two-year notes, the most actively traded issue, rose 2 basis points, to 4.67 percent.
Demand for bonds was also lifted by the Federal Reserve's purchase of $1.04 billion of Treasury securities to add money permanently in the banking system to address a seasonal shortage, traders said.
Shorter-term securities lagged amid expectations that resilience in the economy and a recent rally in stocks will keep the Federal Reserve from cutting interest rates again soon.
"The implication is that the Fed is finished," said Paul Kasriel, an economist at Northern Trust Securities.

HEADLINE: Commercial Real Estate;
Despite Strong Business, Luxury Hotel Renovates

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
The hotel business is still booming in New York. According to the latest figures from PricewaterhouseCoopers, the accounting and consulting firm, the hotel occupancy rate in the fourth quarter is expected to be 84 percent this year, up from 82 percent last year.
"Eighty-four percent is essentially Manhattan's capacity," said Sean F. Hennessy, the New York director of the firm's hospitality and leisure practice. 
 So why did the owners of the Peninsula hotel, on Fifth Avenue at 55th Street, close the doors on Jan. 1 for a $45 million renovation of the turn-of-the-century building? According to Niklaus J. Leuenberger, the general manager, there is no good time to close down, so managers of the Honk Kong-based Peninsula Group decided to proceed with the project.
The hotel has been opening floor by floor this month and is expected to be fully in operation by Dec. 1.
"If the business is up, you don't want to close, but if the business is down, you don't want to invest," Mr. Leuenberger said. He said if the renovation was not performed, the property would deteriorate and possibly not be seen by customers as being in the top luxury category that Peninsula hotels aspire to.
"I told the owners that they can't afford to let the hotel run down," he said. "It wouldn't be a Peninsula."
He said he felt fortunate that the decision to renovate was made before economic problems started becoming obvious in Asian economies. "If we had waited until Asia got soft, the owners might have objected," he said. "In the long run, it was the right thing to do."
The bulk of the renovation focused on the 23-story hotel's 242 guest rooms and suites, with largely cosmetic changes to the restaurants and public spaces. Almost no change was made to the Beaux Arts exterior, which was given landmark status in 1992.
The building of what was known for a long time as the Gotham Hotel began in 1902, when that part of Fifth Avenue was converting to a residential from a commercial neighborhood. Despite its age, the building has a modern steel frame.
Although the stone facade, with its massive pillars and carved decorations, appears substantial enough to support the structure, it is actually hung from the steel framework. This structure allowed the renovators to move interior walls almost at will to reconfigure rooms, add 14 more suites by combining rooms and modernize the electrical and plumbing systems.
As befits a hotel whose room rates start at $535 a night ($455 with a corporate discount), a lot of attention was devoted to making guests comfortable and keeping them occupied. All the windows were replaced by windows with dual panes of different thickness. One pane is designed to shut out high-pitched sounds, the other to resist the deeper rumble of trucks and buses. Moreover, they can be opened.
By the bedside, there is an electronic control panel that regulates the room's temperature, lighting and radio and television. For safety, the panel operates on low voltage, with the 12-volt signals from the panel enabling a black box to operate the 110-volt lights and appliances.
For business travelers, there is a large desk with ports on the front to make it easy to plug in personal computers and high-capacity telephone lines to connect to the Internet. A fax machine is standard for exchanging documents and receiving messages. "The idea is that we don't send messages to the room, we fax them to the room," Mr. Leuenberger said.
The bathrooms were enlarged, both to make them more attractive and to comply with the requirements of the Americans with Disabilities Act regarding wheelchair access. (The lobby facing 55th Street was expanded and two short elevators were added to bring people from the ground floor to mezzanine-level bar and restaurant, moving the rest of the hotel into compliance with the rules for the disabled.
Most rooms come with televisions in the bathroom and a speaker telephone that automatically shuts off the sound of the television when a call comes in. In the larger rooms, there are his and hers shower stalls, and everything in sight is faced in marble.
The hotel's suites range from $800 a night for the smallest units to $7,000 a night for the three-bedroom presidential suite.
Although the Peninsula aims for the top of New York's hotel market ("It's the Four Seasons, the St. Regis and us," Mr. Leuenberger said), the hotel industry in the city is busy at less lofty price levels. In recent weeks, Marriott International has officially opened three hotels in the city. Two are its Courtyard brand, one a new building on 40th Street between Broadway and the Avenue of the Americas and the other in a converted office building on Third Avenue between 52d and 53d Streets.
The third, under the Marriott brand name, is part of the Renaissance Plaza development in Brooklyn, where it was the first new large-scale hotel to open in the borough in nearly 70 years when it started taking guests in July. The hotel includes 376 guest rooms, 27,000 square feet of meeting and convention space and an 18,000-square-foot ballroom, one of the largest in the city.

HEADLINE: C.I.A. Denies That It Withheld Reports on Russian Corruption

BYLINE: By JAMES RISEN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24

 BODY:
The Central Intelligence Agency said today that it had provided many reports on the corruption of senior Russian officials to the Clinton Administration.
The agency strongly denied that its analysts had censored themselves after concluding that senior Administration officials did not want evidence of corruption to obstruct doing business with the Russian leadership. 
 "We have published numerous pieces on corruption in the Russian Government over the past several years and up to the present," said a spokesman for the agency, Bill Harlow. "We do not withhold reports because they are inconvenient."
The statement was a response to an article on Monday in The New York Times.
Some C.I.A. officials, the article reported, said important Administration officials had been dismissive of intelligence reports about the corruption of Russian leaders.
The leaders, the analysts said, included former Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin and Anatoly B. Chubais, who was until recently considered by Administration officials to be a close and important counterpart in the field of economic reform.
The Central Intelligence Agency said today that its analysts had continued to provide reports on high-level Russian corruption, no matter how they are received.
Officials acknowledged frequent tensions between the agency and policy makers over the reporting.
The ability to remain independent in the face of political pressure is a sensitive issue for agency officials. Political pressure on the intelligence community is a recurring theme here.
The debate may have reached a high point in the battle in 1991 over the nomination of Robert Gates to be Director of Central Intelligence.
Mr. Gates, who had been deputy director of the C.I.A. in the Reagan Administration, came under fire at the Senate hearings because of allegations that he had sought to tailor intelligence reports on the Soviet Union to fit the Reagan Administration's conservative policies.
Mr. Gates was confirmed as director.
