HEADLINE: THE GUIDE

BYLINE: By BARBARA DELATINER 

 BODY:

Best Bet
It's beginning to look a lot like Christmas as the fabled Big Duck on Route 24 in Flanders is lighted, to the sound of "duck carols," at 7 P.M. Wednesday (854-4970). Saturday brings other perennials: the EAB Plaza tree lighting at 5:30 P.M. in Uniondale (683-0339); the start, with concerts and a "First Night" party, of Old Westbury Gardens' nine-day Christmas Celebration (333-0048), and the opening of the Winter Festival, with a two-day crafts sale, through Dec. 13, at Planting Fields Arboretum in Oyster Bay (922-9210). 

Free Choices
TODAY St. Nicholas holds forth for family photo ops at the historic St. James General Store on Moriches Road from 12:30 to 4:30 P.M. daily through Dec. 20 (571-7600).
TUESDAY Shimon Peres, the former prime minister of Israel and a winner of the 1994 Nobel Peace Prize, discusses "Israel: The Next 50 Years" at 8 P.M. in the University Center on Adelphi University in Garden City (877-3260).
WEDNESDAY "Truth or Consequences in D.C.," Nassau Community College's lecture series on the Clinton-Lewinsky-Starr confrontation, concludes with an appearance by Dick Morris, the political consultant, at 12:30 P.M. at the College Center in Garden City (572-7153).
SATURDAY Two community orchestras take the stage. The Massapequa Philharmonic, joined by Chee-Yun, violinist, performs Dvorak, Schubert and Sibelius at 8:30 P.M. at Berner Junior High School on Carmans Mill Road. The dress rehearsal on Friday at 8 P.M. will be open to the public (795-4071). The South Shore Philharmonic, with Alex Kirillov, violinist, plays Brahms and Sibelius at 8 P.M. at West Hempstead High School on Nassau Boulevard (599-0444).
 
At the Libraries
Performing works by Bach, Paganini, Prokofiev and Richard Strauss, the mother-and-son duo Yelena Pole zhayev, pianist, and Anton Pole zhayev, violinist, appear at 2 P.M. today at the Long Beach Library (432-7201). Momentum, the mother-daughter team of Kathleen Dougherty, hornist, and Kristine Dougherty, flutist, joined by Henry DeVries, pianist, play Mozert, Schubert and Telemann at 7:30 P.M. Friday at the Bayport-Blue Point Library on Blue Point (363-6133). Tomorrow at 8 P.M., the Port Washington Library screens "Arguing the World," the filmmaker Joseph Dorman's discussion with the political thinkers Irving Howe, Daniel Bell, Nathan Glazer and Irving Kristol (883-4400). Plaza Theatrical Productions brings its fully staged version of "South Pacific" to the Plainview-Old Bethpage Library in Plainview at 8 P.M. Friday and Saturday (938-0077).
 
Observing AIDS Day
Three World AIDS Day commemorations on the Island this year feature "Facing AIDS: Photographic Portraits from Long Island" by Rick Miller. Today from 1 to 6 P.M., the AIDS Collective/Names Project Long Island, St. Mary's Parish and Interfaith Long Island hold "A Day of Remembrance" at Sacred Heart Hall and the AIDS Memorial Garden at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church on Montauk Highway in East Islip. The observance includes the exhibition of the Names Project AIDS Memorial Quilt and visits to the garden (505-1853). Mr. Miller's work is on display through next Sunday at the Heckscher Museum on Prime Avenue in Huntington (351-3250).
On Tuesday, the photographs will be seen at the Amityville Middle School on Route 110, where groups from Nassau and Suffolk observe the day from 7 to 9 P.M. with a candle-lighting ceremony, music and the announcement of the winners of the annual "Write for Life" essay and art contest (377-4242).
In other AIDS Day activities, the Parrish Art Museum on Job's Lane in Southampton shows "Dear Death," a collection of personal letters written by Bronx children and their families affected by AIDS. The display runs from tomorrow through next Sunday (283-2118). Next Sunday, there's a non-sectarian World AIDS Day service at 4 P.M. at the Cathedral of the Incarnation in Garden City remembering those lives have been impacted by AIDS (746-2955).
 
Voices Raised
After months of rehearsals, vocal groups on the Island this week start doing the thing they do at least twice a year, at Christmas and Easter: sing holiday concerts. The seasonal rush begins today when the Hofstra Chamber Singers journey to Christ Church on Main Street in Oyster Bay to perform a program that includes Britten's "Ceremony of Carols" and settings by Villette and Britten of "Hymns to the Virgin" at 3 P.M. (463-6644). Britten's "Ceremony of Carols" is again featured on Thursday at 8 P.M., when the Adelphi Chorus performs its free holiday concert at home in the University Center on the Garden City campus
(877-4290).
On Saturday, four choral music concerts are scheduled. The North Fork Chorale sings the first of four seasonal concerts at the Cutchogue Methodist Church (734-4174)The Waldorf Choral Society sings Vivaldi's "Gloria"and Hummel's "Mass in E" at 8 P.M. at the Cathedral of the Incarnation on Cathedral Avenue in Garden City (742-3434). The Oceanside Chorale celebrates Christmas and Hanukkah, with its "Musical Holiday" featuring Handel's "Judas Maccabeus" and Gounod's "Sanctus" at 8 P.M. at the Middle School on Alice Avenue (223-6120). The North Shore Community Chorus, joined by the Gloria Dei Lutheran Choir, perform Schubert's "Mass in G" and "Magnificat" at 8 P.M. at Trinity Episcopal Church on Northern Boulevard in Roslyn (671-5500, extension 143).
 
Soprano's Return
There's nothing like an alumna returning triumphantly to the campus that helped train her. That is what Christine Goerke, a native of Medford, will do on Tuesday when she gives the annual alumni concert at the State University at Stony Brook. In the few seasons since her professional debut, Ms. Goerke, a soprano who is a product of the Metropolitan Opera's Young Artist Development Program, has sung major roles at the Met, the Glimmerglass Opera in Cooperstown, N.Y., and the Opera Theater of St. Louis. She has also appeared in concert with the New York Philharmonic, the Atlanta Symphony and the Orchestra of St. Luke's. Her concert, a preview of her Carnegie Hall recital on Friday, is at 8 P.M. at Staller Center, and in May she is to return to another alma mater, Suffolk Community College in Selden, where she studied from 1987 to 1989 (632-2787).
 
John Tesh Live
Those who are absolutely wild about John Tesh can see him perform on Thursday and, in the best tradition of killing two birds with one stone, be charitable as well. The first 200 people who buy "WALK's Holiday CD," a record of 10 Christmas standards, will receive a pair of free tickets to the concert at 8 P.M. at the Gateway Playhouse on South Country Road in Bellport. The $10 for the CD goes to 10 children's charities chosen by listeners of WALK-FM in Patchogue. The CD's with the free tickets (one pair per customer) may be purchased only at Gateway's box office at the Patchogue Theater, where the playhouse will present "Nutcracker on Ice" from Dec. 17 through 29 (286-1133).
 
Dickens Festival
Charles Dickens never visited Port Jefferson. But since he was a pillar of the Victorian era and since the quaint waterfront village harks back to the same period, his name is taken (not in vain, the local economic development council hopes) for a pre-holiday celebration. Hence the Charles Dickens Festival, Friday through next Sunday throughout the village. The activities on Friday include a lantern procession down Main Street at 6 P.M.and a free concert by Peter Duchin and his orchestra at 7:30 P.M. at the Jefferson Street School. Saturday's highlights include an ice sculpture display at 1 P.M. at Bayles Park; a "Dickens Filmfest" from noon to 4 P.M. at the library, and a Victorian Candlelight House Tour at 5 P.M. On Sunday, there are children's shows at 1 and 2 P.M. at the Jefferson School, and Douglas Broyles portrays the novelist in "Charles Dickens in Person," at 1 and 2 P.M. at the library. Each day there will be Victorian carriage rides, caroling and instrumental music concerts, and rides on "The Little Red Trolley" (473-4724).
 
Busy Tilles Weekend
Twyla Tharp brings her new company, Tharp!, to Tilles Center in Brookville on Friday with three new works: "Roy's Joy," "The Fugue" and "Sweet Fields." On Saturday, in keeping with the calendar, Aengus, Robbie O'Connell's musical troupe, offers a "Celtic Christmas Celebration." Joined by Eileen Johnson and John Jennings, Irish step dancers, the quartet of traditional musicians will explore the Christian and pagan traditions surrounding the winter solstice in a mixture of songs and instrumental pieces. Both concerts are at 8 P.M. on the C. W. Post campus (299-3100). BARBARA DELATINER

HEADLINE: Made, Marketed and Sold Here

BYLINE: By STEPHEN L. PURDY 

 BODY:
IN the early 90's, Hank Paine, whose family had owned the Howland-Hughes department store in Waterbury since 1922, ran a "staying in business" sale. Like other independent retailers, the store had been affected by a slow economy and the competition of malls, and so it was reinventing itself. A quarter of Howland-Hughes's original space would now house The Connecticut Store, all of whose products were made in the state.
Though Mr. Paine said he knew the "diversity, quality, innovation and price" of the goods would be their selling points, he also knew the challenge of the goods not being known to customers. 
 While he doesn't single out any one reason for the state's products and services not being known, he illustrates it by citing a purchasing problem when beginning the new business. He said he was impressed by Waterbury Neckwear, a producer on the same street as the store (but part of the M. Aron Corporation of South Norwalk), and so he decided to order from them.
The process was like following a maze. After being shuttled to his neighbor's New York office, then to a Las Vegas trade show, he ordered four dozen ties -- which did not make it to the store. He said he finally made an arrangement with the manager of the Waterbury operation, and "the store got ties."
Mr. Paine described keeping in touch with small but thriving state businesses who sold products at his store and who shared similar frustrations. Matthew Bristow, the chief executive officer of the felt and blanket maker Charles W. House & Sons in Unionville, and Brooks H. Titcomb, president of Woodbury Pewter, and Mr. Paine realized they needed an organization to compete, and out of these informal talks grew the Made in Connecticut Guild Ltd.
The Guild is a year-old nonprofit organization of some 40 members who pay dues and have twin goals: to educate retailers and consumers that these products are here.
"Connecticut residents will buy Connecticut first," Mr. Paine says in a kind of creed, if "the product is at least equal in quality and price -- and they know about it."
Key marketing strategies begin in the Howland-Hughes department store. Next to a display for blankets by Charles W. House, which the store presents as comparable to or better than those from L. L. Bean of Maine, the customer sees an enlargement from the Bean catalogue, with its higher prices. Mr. Paine explains that, with retail spending in the state estimated at $70 million a year, the customer who chooses the local blanket makes a difference. "Any fractional change, not because of patriotism but because the manufacturers' earned it, is mind-blowing," he says.
A glance around the store shows products from Knitworks of Harwinton, the Great American Puzzle Factory of South Norwalk, Old Saybrook Pottery Place of Sharon and the Woodpecker of Westbrook. Even the restaurant serves coffee roasted in Hartford and tea from R. C. Bigelow in Fairfield.
Formal promotion by the Guild includes advertising in all media, at hotels, with tourism bureaus and on the Internet. The Internet, Mr. Paine says, is particularly useful for people who used to live in the state but now live elsewhere.
Advertising has had a recent boost from popular culture. The store is an outlet for Waterbury Companies Inc., a nearly two-century-old manufacturer of buttons that has supplied the military and municipal services, sports tournaments and clothing makers as well as the crew of the Titanic; it's now "the worldwide marketer and distributor for the replicas of Titanic uniform buttons," Mr. Paine said.
Mr. Titcomb, of Woodbury Pewter, sees a role for the Guild in organizing and coordinating information. For instance, after the Guild caught the eye of the Governor and the state's Department of Economic and Community Development at an Eastern States Exposition, Mr. Titcomb says, the state agency referred out-of-state inquiries for statemade products to the Guild.
"Purchasers contacted the state, which in turn called us," he said.
And Mr. Bristow, of Charles W. House, said the Guild persuaded him to open a retail outlet last year which, like The Connecticut Store, sells statemade products. "That decision took me from serving just the industrial market," he said, "and would never have been made without the soft-nudging of the Guild."
Mr. Paine says local initiatives may encourage state manufacturers to centralize, placing porcelain and glass enamel, for example, or pewter and engraving, in the same building, preferably at a crossroads like Hartford, Danbury or Mystic.
The Guild also works on companies' awareness of other businesses in their own backyards. One of the biggest company-meets-company stories is Waterbury Leatherworks and Charles W. House. The result: collaborative manufacture of a handbag that now hangs in the center of the store.
The Danbury Square Box Company, one of the store's vendors with products not finished for retail, has acquired three new accounts in joining the Guild. "I expect to get more business," said the company's president, John Allen, also a Guild board member.
Mr. Paine explained that such cooperation was born at the end of a long road of indifference by advertisers and producers not considering Connecticut a market. In recent years, he adds, this negligence was fueled by business downturns and uncertainties, like those at Stanley Works and Electric Boat, Pratt & Whitney and Sikorsky.
"Then our own Department of Economic and Community Development said it was proud to announce the transition from manufacturing to service," Mr. Paine said. "Would you say that's an environment conducive to 'Made in Connecticut'?"
But the state is now keeping its own doors open, he added, and the overall climate is changing.
Indeed, a spokesman for the Department of Economic and Community Development, Chris Cooper, says that, although his department has not provided the Guild with financial assistance, its exhibit at the Eastern States Exposition was "one of the most popular."
The Guild has found perhaps its biggest friend in the Manufacturing Alliance of Connecticut, whose main legislative issues are workers' and unemployment compensation, energy initiatives and taxes.
"Anything that could help a manufacturing company grow, expand or remain in Connecticut" is welcome says the Alliance's executive director, Frank J. Johnson.
"If in two or three years 'Made in Connecticut' is a household thought," said Mr. Titcomb, "we go beyond there, much as 'Made in Vermont' products has."
Mr. Paine said he believes that, all things being equal, Connecticut residents will buy first in their state. "And we don't have equal quality and price -- we're better," he said.

HEADLINE: THEATER;
A Woman in Black Fascinated by Rouge

BYLINE: By ALVIN KLEIN 

 BODY:
IT takes the real thing to play the real thing. Tovah Feldshuh is a genuine, bona fide character actress and Diana Vreeland was the exemplar of artifice as heightened reality. In the Theater Works production of "Full Gallop" in Hartford, the two of them are one.
If the old-fangled designation character actor isn't being used much anymore, it's because its practitioners are hard to find. Ms. Feldshuh's total immersion into another being lifts the word versatility from show business hyperbole to communicative art. In a notable career, she has transformed herself into a Talmudic student disguised as a boy, a lusty Latin widow, a smothering and smoldering Jewish mother, a withering Jewish grandmother, a flamboyant star of stage and screen. And we're still counting. 
 Summoning her considerable experience as a cabaret performer, Ms. Feldshuh draws the audience in as the role's creator, Mary Louise Wilson, did not. She will offer you rouge or put aside a crystal vase of flowers that obstructs someone's sight line. But if you're crinkling a candy wrapper, beware.
Never misplacing the hauteur of the fabled "Oracle of Beauty" and "High Priestess of Fashion" (actually high and low, for "a splash of bad taste" was necessary to Mrs. Vreeland; it was no taste that offended), Ms. Feldshuh deflates pretense with one imperious look.
With the eternal self-esteem that true devotion between human beings bequeaths, she also tells a love story through spare references to a dapper man, Thomas R. Vreeland. Her recollection of his illness, the last chapter of their 40-year marriage, is an object lesson in the precision and economy of acting.
But first things first. "I am out of a job," Mrs. Vreeland declares. Musing on her last day as editor in chief of Vogue, she startlingly recalls being told "Your future is behind you."
Ms. Feldshuh's exaggerated vocal attack, a multi-lingual drawl, is a wildly theatrical realization of Mrs. Vreeland's idiocyncratic accent, which was described by Christopher Hemphill, her collaborator on the gorgeous book of photographs and commentary, "Allure," published in 1980, as "rococo speech."
"Her voice itself almost allows one to see the italics she speaks in," Mr. Hemphill wrote of Mrs. Vreeland "for whom the tape recorder might have been invented."
And wait till you see her, a spider woman in black, "fascinated by rouge," stalking about in a flower flooded apartment ("You can never have enough flowers," she pronounces) of flaming red ("bright, cleansing, revealing red"). If Michael Schweikardt's evocative set design is not really scented, no one wants to know.
Ms. Feldshuh's grand Tony Award-nominated performance as Signora Maria Merelli, the tempestuous wife of a temperamental opera singer in "Lend Me A Tenor," can now be perceived as a dress rehearsal for this new star turn. Whatever the behind-the-scenes power struggle or the hard-core facts of business accounted for her dismissal from Vogue, it is the divinely biased account of a spectacularly instinctual icon that matters. Besides, it isn't long before she agrees to be a consultant to the Costume Institute of the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York -- her last professional blaze of glory.
"You give them what they never knew they wanted," is how Mrs. Vreeland sums up a singular uncompetitive rule of success. "Nobody gives a damn about authenticity if it's ugly," she declares. "I want to be drowned in beauty."
It comes as a surprise, a treat and, finally, a revelation to be unutterably moved by an image of largesse from whom you reasonably expect to feel distanced. She remembers a childhood of privilege -- seeing Isadora Duncan, Pavlova, Nijinksy -- and recounts a fabulous life (knowing everybody). "It is beauty that is leaving this world," she bemoans, all too prophetically. "There was a time people never ceased perfecting themselves."
Whether she is appreciating the tonality of color -- "magentas and mauves," "the orange of Diaghilev, the orange that changed the century," or the blue of the Duke of Windsor's eyes, his "azure aura," or relishing one puff of a Lucky Strike, Ms. Feldshuh imparts the essence of enjoyment.
Rob Ruggiero's graceful staging is a knowing acknowledgment of the skill and craft with which Mary Louise Wilson and Mark Hampton wrote the very model of a seamless one-woman piece (with funny French maid on the intercom) and the wit of Ms. Feldshuh's playing -- truly, she plays -- is a testament to the eccentricities and the resilience of an original character who may have invented the flair for reinvention. This is high theater.
 
"Full Gallop," Hutensky Theater, 233 Pearl Street, Hartford. (860) 527-7838. Performances through Dec. 6.

HEADLINE: Stock Tournaments Find Ready Combatants in Younger Generation

BYLINE: By BARBARA HALL 

DATELINE: NEW ROCHELLE

 BODY:
PETER LYNCH, the mutual fund manager and stock investment analyst, wrote a book with John Rothchild, former financial columnist for Time, called "One Up on Wall Street" (Simon & Schuster). In it, he told about venturing into an elementary school where he interviewed youngsters on their favorite products: clothing, foods, toys. He then made investments based on those conversations. The result was alchemy. Mr. Lynch profited nicely.
Darren Gurney, a social studies teacher at New Rochelle High School here, had an explanation. "Kids, who are in a sense not distracted by all the professional analysis, all the talk on the street, can sometimes get to the heart of things," he said. A case in point: Mr. Gurney's Entrepreneur Club at the school, which is holding its own in a student stock tournament co-sponsored by CNBC, the cable financial network. 
 The contest, now in its second year, has attracted more than 2,500 teams from the United States and Canada. Several of the clubs are from Westchester, with names like the '29ers of Mamaroneck, the Husky Traders of Harrison, Dark Wind of the Masters School in Dobbs Ferry and the Alstars of Rye -- more than a dozen in all.
"I find the team turnout very encouraging," said Bill Griffeth, a CNBC anchorman and the tournament director. "The perception of most students probably was that investment was, A, for older people or, B, for rich people. Investment should be for everybody, and especially for this generation."
At issue is what he called financial literacy.
"We felt that this younger generation -- who would not have Social Security to deal with, would not have pensions to benefit from -- needs to take control of their financial futures. The best way to do this is to teach them as early as possible about investing. So, by October of last year the whole idea came together to put this competition on our Web site.
"What we're finding is this generation is going to do all right; they have it in them to do it. These kids are bright, and they bring to the contest a natural curiosity they will need in the future."
The tournament works this way: initially, each team gets $100,000 in what CNBC calls "fantasy funds" -- hypothetical money. This will be used to invest in stocks on the New York Stock Exchange and the Nasdaq/AMEX Market group. The team that fares best at the close of the semester will receive 250 shares of General Electric common stock, valued at about $20,000.
Teams with the highest weekly percentage gains in their portfolio are featured on CNBC. So far, several Westchester teams have been among those recognized.
The contest rules have been refined since last year. For example, to counter what Mr. Griffeth called "day trading frenzy" on the part of student investors, organizers established commissions. By doing so, CNBC reasoned that the young people would be prompted to take a long-term view.
A sweep of the Westchester schools reveals a spectrum of team makeup and methods.
The majority are high school groups that meet once a week with a faculty adviser to review investment standings and strategy. The '29ers are an example of the norm. As William Beaver, a senior active in the club, explained recently: "Basically, we hold weekly meetings. We have about 30 kids subdivided into 5 groups of 6. We tabulate which small group has the best returns, and they pick the stocks for the following week."
Then, too, there is the team of three 10th-grade girls from the Masters School, a private elementary and high school in Dobbs Ferry. They go by the name of Jacyurmar, a fusion of the first three letters of each girl's first name. The girls said they meet for an average of 20 minutes a day to see how the market is affecting their holdings. "I've definitely learned from this," Marissa Riviello, one of the girls, said. "It's fun."
And there is Mr. Gurney's Entrepreneurs. The club predates CNBC's tournament. Founded several years ago, the group is a mixture of grades and races. Its members include Brandon Woods and Irene Morales, both seniors.
As her club's lone girl, Irene said: "At first, I was really intimidated by the others who knew what they were doing. I guess I've learned since then, that as much as people think this is a man's world, a woman can be involved. With a will to succeed, anything's possible."
Brandon, too, is upbeat, based on his three years with the club. "I think, with the economy doing well, there's definitely momentum for minorities in the market," he said. "I read things like Black Enterprise, and I'm finding there's much opportunity for us. I really have learned from this contest. It has made me think about being a stockbroker, a trader, in the future."
With Mr. Gurney as supervisor, the New Rochelle team has to perform a balancing act, considering the students' varying approaches to the market. For instance, Michael Queller, a self-described gambler, takes an aggressive stance, with the club and in his personal investments. Mr. Gurney is also more than a player on paper. The two often meet informally during the day to compare notes. "Whatever company I'm invested in at home, I'm invested in for the school competition," Michael said.
His approach is tempered by Rick Gottlieb, the team researcher -- Mr. Gurney's term -- and Brandon, who takes an interest in both history and the long term.
Mr. Gurney seems to take satisfaction from the club.
"I tell my students, 'I just want you to be passionate about something in life, whether it's stocks, sports, drama, history,' " he said. "When we have stock club meetings, the kids are definitely passionate. It's enjoyable to be around."
No report on school investment clubs in Westchester would be complete without mention of the Hackley Hornets of the Hackley School in Tarrytown. Last year they placed first in the CNBC tournament. School administrators are now considering how to use the club's winnings of $18,000. Their choices include authorizing students to invest the money in the market, using the money to start a scholarship fund or putting the money in the school's general fund.
The Hornets' faculty adviser, Jenny Lyons, called Aaron Siegel the force behind the school's victory. Aaron is looking into new competitions for the investment club, one of which is sponsored by the Federal Reserve Bank.
As for the CNBC tournament, Aaron said: "It takes the mists away from how the market works and allows you to see how it actually is. For us, it has been a remarkable experience."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Darren Gurney, a social studies teacher at New Rochelle High School, standing center, supervises members of the school's stock market club. From left: Rick Gottlieb, Michael Fitzsimmons and Brandon Woods. (Chris Maynard for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Will the Patriots Draw in Fairfield?

BYLINE: By JACK CAVANAUGH 

 BODY:
BELIEVING that his team needed corporate support from Fairfield County if it was to survive in Hartford, Richard Gordon, then the principle owner of the Hartford Whalers hockey team, invited 146 executives from the region to attend a reception, dinner and a Whalers' hockey game in February of 1992.
As it developed, only six people showed up, convincing Mr. Gordon that, when it came to big league sports, Fairfield County was strictly attuned to New York (and New Jersey) teams -- something he had suspected all along. 
 In large measure because they were unable to attract fans from the southwestern part of the state, along with corporations that might buy high-priced sky boxes, the Whalers eventually left Connecticut for North Carolina in 1997. Now, amid the euphoria surrounding the projected move of the New England Patriots of the National Football League to Hartford in 2001, a key question remains: Will enough corporations from Fairfield County, including the 14 that are included on the Fortune 500 list, pay up to $100,000 a year for one of the 150 or so luxury suites at the proposed 68,000-seat stadium along the Connecticut River near downtown Hartford?
"That is clearly a major concern for the Patriots," said Joseph McGee, vice president of the Southwestern Connecticut Area Commerce and Industry Association, which represents about 600 companies in Fairfield County. "Nobody knows whether they'll get that corporate support in an area where most fan loyalty is with New York teams."
As the State Commissioner for Economic Development under Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr., Mr. McGee was involved in earlier efforts, in 1993 and 1994, to lure the Patriots to Hartford with the promise of building a 70,000-seat stadium with $252 million that had been authorized by the Connecticut legislature. "At the time some interest in luxury boxes was expressed by corporations from Fairfield County," Mr. McGee said. "Whether there would still be interest today, I don't know. But I personally think there will be a lot more interest in the Patriots in Fairfield County than some people think. For one thing, it will take about the same amount of time to get to the Patriots' stadium in Hartford from Stamford as it does from Stamford to the Meadowlands."
Many football fans in Connecticut root for the New York Giants, who trained at Fairfield University in the late 1950's and in the 60's (when Andy Robustelli of Stamford was a star defensive end) and who played their home games at the Yale Bowl in 1973 and 1974 while Yankee Stadium, then their home field, was being renovated. By comparison, a much smaller number of Connecticut fans pull for the Jets, who began play as the New York Titans in 1959, 34 years after the Giants joined the National Football League, and who, like the Giants, play their home games at Giants Stadium in East Rutherford, N.J. But there are long waiting lists for season tickets for both teams, and for luxury boxes, which Mr. McGee said, could make the Patriots in Hartford attractive to at least some fans -- and corporations -- in Fairfield County.
"If you're boxed out of getting season tickets for Giants and Jets' games, tickets for Patriot games could be attractive," Mr. McGee said, "and I think some companies would buy them."
At present the Patriots' fan base in Connecticut is mainly confined to the northeastern part of the state. Some sports analysts say that even in Hartford -- which is 100 miles from Foxboro, Mass., where the Patriots play their home games -- the Patriots are a second choice in fan support to the Giants, whose home base is 125 miles away.
That should change, though, if the Patriots do indeed move to Hartford, a move that is contingent on the the General Assembly authorizing a $350 million bond issue for a new stadium. But it is not likely to alter the rooting pattern of Giants and Jets fans in the lower part of the state. "There's a loyalty that has been built up over the years for a team like the Giants in Fairfield County," said Herb Kohn, a longtime Stamford sports activist who has had season tickets for Giants' home games since 1955. "And you don't change it by having another team move into the state. I personally think they're going to have to develop a new following," he said of the Patriots.
If they do, that new following will be complemented by thousands of die-hard Patriot fans from Massachusetts and Rhode Island who are expected to continue to hold on to their season tickets for Patriot games in Hartford. Indeed, at present there is a four-year waiting period to buy season tickets to Patriot games at the 57,000-seat Foxboro Stadium. If anything, that may limit the availability of seats for Connecticut residents -- although the proposed stadium would have about 11,000 more seats.
No one knows what kind of support a Patriot team would get from residents in an area not renown for football, unlike Charlotte, Nashville and Jacksonville, which in recent years have acquired National Football League franchises. Apart from the glory days of Yale football -- from the 1930's through the 60's -- and the intense rivalries between high schools in the Naugatuck Valley, which have drawn big crowds at games in Ansonia, Derby, Shelton, Seymour and Naugatuck, Connecticut has not been regarded as a hotbed of football. "But there's a big difference when you talk about an N.F.L. team, compared to high school football," said Owen Canfield, the veteran sports columnist for The Hartford Courant. "An N.F.L. franchise in Hartford can't possibly fail."
Assuming the memorandum of understanding between Gov. John G. Rowland and the Patriots' owner, Robert Kraft, evolves into a signed contract, the Patriots' move to Hartford will prove a boon to the University of Connecticut football program. The university's board of trustees late last year approved a plan to upgrade the football team from Division I-AA to Division I-A. But the plan died aborning when the General Assembly turned down a $35 million bond issue to cover the cost of a new stadium on the Storrs campus that was needed to meet seating requirements of the National Collegiate Athletic Association for Division I-A.
Now, if a stadium is built for the Patriots as part of the billion-dollar Adriaen's Landing project along the Connecticut River near the intersection of Interstates 91 and 84, the UConn football team will be able to share the stadium and thus play on the Division I-A level. The UConn Athletic Director, Lew Perkins, who has been a strong proponent of such a move, is convinced that a UConn football team in the upper echelon of college football would draw large crowds while playing other Big East teams such as Miami and Syracuse.
The Huskies have never drawn well at 16,000-seat Memorial Stadium on the Storrs campus or attracted large statewide interest. "It's a totally different situation when you play on the Division I-A level," Mr. Perkins has said in his effort to to elevate the football program to the higher level. "People from all over will come to see UConn play, say, Syracuse and Miami."
While the Patriots' fan base in Fairfield County remains to be seen, the proposal to build a rent-free stadium for the team has drawn support from several key Fairfield County legislators of both major political parties. State Senator William H. Nickerson, a Greenwich Republican, who is regarded as a conservative on fiscal matters, has endorsed the plan, describing it as "truly urban renewal" since it includes a convention center, hotel, parking and other features. State Senator George C. Jepsen, a Stamford Democrat and the Senate majority leader, has said he also favors the plan. That came as a surprise since Mr. Jepsen had opposed state funds to build a football stadium on the UConn camps.
"Getting the Patriots will enhance the image of the entire state," Mr. Jepsen said, "and it's probably the only chance Connecticut will ever have to get an N.F.L. team. It's an incredible opportunity."
As for the impact on Fairfield County, Mr. Jepsen said that, among other things, "Hartford will now become one more entertainment option for people in the county." Agreeing with Governor Rowland, the senator said he thought that the stadium will pay for itself through a 10 percent surcharge on tickets and from income tax revenue from players' salaries. "If the state has to put out any money, I think the state subsidy will be small," he said.
Drawing an analogy with bipartisan support that often backs a President on foreign policy in Washington, Mr. Jepsen, who often opposes initiatives from Mr. Rowland, said, "As far as we're concerned in Connecticut, this is foreign policy, and we're standing behind the Governor."
 
When Hartford Was in N.F.L.
 IF the New England Patriots do move to Hartford, it will mark a homecoming of sorts for the National Football League.
Not many people remember it, but in 1926, the league's seventh year of existence, a team known as the Hartford Blues played its home games at the East Hartford Velodrome, a stadium that had been built for bicycle racing.
Plagued by bad weather and a weak team composed mainly of players from the Hartford area with names like Furlong Flynn, Lefty Jamerson and Mule Werwaiss, the Blues won three games and lost seven while playing in front of home crowds that ranged from 6,500, against the New York Giants, and 500 against the Kansas City Cowboys.
By the next season, though, the Blues had been voted out of the league, which had decided to cut back to 12 teams from 22.
If the Patriots do move to Hartford, they will do so with a 30-year lease arrangement, insuring that they would last longer than the Hartford Blues. JACK CAVANAUGH

HEADLINE: The View From/Collin's Diner, Canaan;
Giving a Voice to Poetry, Lebanese Zest to a Menu

BYLINE: By FRANCES CHAMBERLAIN 

 BODY:
COLLIN'S DINER of Canaan is a traditional place. The National Historic Landmark, built in 1941, is also a local landmark in the village's restored railroad depot center. The diner, which is open seven days a week, attracts plenty of regulars as well as travelers on Route 7.
Sometimes, however, what patrons are expecting is not exactly what they get. The owners, Aida and Mohammed Abo-Hamzy, encouraged their son, Ameen Storm Abo-Hamzy, to begin a monthly poetry reading in 1994, and since then the little diner has been filled one night a month with people from New York and Massachusetts as well as from Connecticut. Everything looks just the same, but guests might get free verse served up with their meatloaf and potatoes. 
 For the October reading, while a few regular customers finished dinner -- on this night traditional Lebanese cooking -- ghouls, grim reapers and Draculas mingled with children dressed as bunnies and storybook characters.
Once the dinner hour was over, Mr. Abo-Hamzy started with his own rendition of the song "Never Give Up On You." Students from Housatonic Valley Regional High School, Explorations Charter School in Winsted and the Forman School in Litchfield signed up to read their work while a panel of randomly selected judges rated them on costume, presentation and poem.
Mr. Abo-Hamzy's poetry series has featured published poets like Susan Kinsolving of Bridgewater, Dennis Finnell of Amherst, Mass.; Honor Moore of Kent; Courtney Davis of Redding; William DeVoti of Sheffield, Mass., and Michelle Gilette of Stockbridge, Mass. Faith Vincenzanza, who coordinates Connecticut's poetry slams, and members of the Litchfield Monday Poets group -- Julia Bolus, Davyne Verstandig, Sandra Bishop Ebner and Cheryl Boutenoff -- have also joined in the series.
"It has been a real mix of people," Mr. Abo-Hamzy said. "Some of them are published and well known, others aren't. Clea Fowler, for instance, is young and unpublished, but an incredible poet."
The first formal reading was a historic event, Mr. Abo-Hamzy said. "Oliver Eldridge, who published 'Beach Grass,' came, along with Andrew Gromiller and The Organically Grown. I met him in the gas station and asked him to perform. His work is a sort of folksy-rock with a gospel voice," Mr. Abo-Hamzy said. "Some readings draw as few as five people, others a full house," he explained. "We fit everybody in. You might have to sit with someone you don't know, but that is part of bringing everyone together." Guests at the diner, whether or not they are there for a poetry reading, are encouraged to go from booth to booth reading the poetry series framed over the center of each table.
A recent series featured work by Mr. Abo-Hamzy: "The first showcase of poetry was poems in memory of friends who had died of AIDS," he said. "While I lived in New York I had so many friends who died. AIDS was claiming one to two people I knew each week because I was involved in the business of music, hairstyling and theater. It was unfathomable."
Mr. Abo-Hamzy's path through life led him from his hometown of Canaan to New York and back again. He graduated from Housatonic Valley Regional High School and then went to Norwich University, the military college of Vermont. "I got a ROTC scholarship; I liked the discipline," he said. "I was commissioned a second lieutenant in the U.S. Army and graduated with a degree in English literature from Norwich." As a paratrooper in the Airborne, he was discharged early because of an injury. "Then I went to Manhattan and became a waiter while I learned to cut hair," he explained. "Waiting tables was the most lucrative way to make money in the city. I'd done it all my life; what could be simpler? When my Dad got sick, I decided to come back to Connecticut."
Mr. Abo-Hamzy's parents have owned and run the Collin's Diner since 1969.
Now he helps his mother run the diner, in addition to a variety of other artistic pursuits. "I've always been a writer, as far back as I can remember. My first poetry reading was in eighth grade," he said. "I try to create three to four pieces a day, not necessarily finished product." In addition to poetry, he said he is working on short stories and a novel as well as studying for a master's degree at Wesleyan University and serving on the board of the Litchfield County Writers Project at University of Connecticut, Torrington.
Cutting hair gives him the money to keep the poetry series alive. "You've got to do what you've got to do to do what you love best," he said. "I wanted to establish this series on my own hard effort. I didn't want it to seem a given. At first, it started as something to do in the country when there wasn't much to do in the summer."
Although attendance can wane in the winter months, a "Poetry Is Music" program in July has become a crowd pleaser. This outdoor open-mike with musicians and poets festival, featuring his mother's Lebanese cooking, is held as part of Canaan Railroad Days. "The diner is a backdrop and the parking lot is our amphitheater," Mr. Abo-Hamzy said. "The money I get from hair cutting goes into promotion. My parents donate electricity and food for performers. The artists donate their time. I tell them I can feed them, but not pay them."
Hummus, tabouleh, stuffed grape leaves and cinnamon rice are often on the menu. "It's whatever she decides," Mr. Abo-Hamzy said. "She used to spend all day making hamburgers and pancakes and then go home and spend three hours making stuffed grape leaves for us." Poetry readings have helped to bring in people hungry for something other than hamburgers.
"I always try to have a published feature poet, or someone well known, and then an open mike afterwards," Mr. Abo-Hamzy said. "I didn't want to do slams. I wanted people just to get up and share their words. So much of the world is about economics. I didn't want art to be about that. The reason I started this series was not about making money; only last year did I put a jar out. I just ran out of money."
Poetry readings continue on the fourth Thursday of every month at 7:30 P.M. though the next featured reader, Michael D'Onofrio, will appear on Dec. 10 instead of the fourth Thursday in deference to the holidays. "Mr. D'Onofrio's earnest poetry will be celebrating the holiday season and the first year of his new son's life," Mr. Abo-Hamzy said.
January's reading will be a surprise, and the Feb. 18th reading, the fourth anniversary of the series, will feature Hugh Ogden, a professor at Trinity College in Hartford and the author of the recently published book "Gift."

HEADLINE: WORKING;
When a Boss Turns Abusive

BYLINE: By MICHELLE COTTLE; Michelle Cottle is a Washington writer.

 BODY:

Q. I recently received a promotion, but my new boss dislikes me and has been verbally abusive, to the point of using an obscene term to describe me in front of my colleagues. (I reported the incident to the department head.) Obviously, this behavior can't go on. What are my rights? Can I sue?

A. In America, everyone has the right to sue. You could claim defamation of character or infliction of emotional harm. With luck, Judge Judy would hear your case on TV. But that wouldn't necessarily solve the problem. 
 Your recent promotion indicates that your grievance isn't with the company, but with the cretin to whom you've been assigned. You need to target your counterattack more precisely than with a lawsuit. In short, it's time to get personal.
First, do a little detective work, advises Joel Neuman, director of the Center for Applied Management at the State University of New York at New Paltz. "Is this common?" he asked. "Has your manager done this to others?" If so, you have additional ammunition for your case. If not, you may find that your boss has short-term personal problems that are making him hot-tempered.
After sizing up the situation, confront your tormentor privately (and quickly, since you've spoken to the department head). When you aren't in the heat of the moment, the two of you just might be able to resolve -- or at least clarify -- the problem.
The step you've already taken -- going over your boss's head -- should have been a last resort. The outcome is rarely happy; the sad reality is that management (like the rest of us) often suffers from an us-versus-them mentality, and just finding a senior person to back you up can be a nightmare.
For instance, if the department head hired and trained your nemesis, he's probably your boss's ally, said Gary Namie, a psychologist in Benicia, Calif., who started the Campaign Against Workplace Bullying. In that case, you'll need to go even higher up the chain of command. Assuming that you find a sympathetic ear, take care when outlining your complaint. Don't expect management to take you seriously if you get all weepy. Lay out your case as impersonally as possible and try to show how the situation is hurting the department's performance, Mr. Namie said. Wonder aloud whether your boss's actions have become apparent to customers or are undermining staff morale.
To avoid the your-word-against-his trap, try to round up witnesses. Most employees will be less than eager to get involved, but you can probably convince a few to confirm public incidents. Your boss's habit of carrying on like a deranged harpy in front of others should make this easier.
Of course, even if you succeed and your boss is reprimanded, you can expect relations to worsen radically. Consider pushing for reassignment to a new manager or division. Barring that, it may be time to start thinking about moving on. If you thought your boss was unpleasant to begin with, just wait until he learns that you've squealed.
 
Michelle Cottle is a Washington writer. Each week, she will respond to readers' questions about career and workplace issues. Send them by E-mail to working@nytimes.com or by mail to Working, Money & Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036.

HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living In / Valley Cottage, N.Y.;
A Diverse, Close-In Rural Hamlet

BYLINE: By CHERYL PLATZMAN WEINSTOCK 

 BODY:
WHEN Chinazo and Everett Cunningham began to feel a little cramped in their 1920's colonial in Nyack they looked for a bigger house on a quieter street in the same neighborhood.
But when they couldn't find the home they wanted in Nyack, Dr. Cunningham, an internist at Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx, and her husband, director of international training and development at Pfizer Inc. in Manhattan, were troubled. "We didn't want to leave the town, or the school district," said Dr. Cunningham. 
 But about five minutes away, nestled between Nyack and Congers, the Cunninghams found a home in the small, rural, hamlet of Valley Cottage in the Town of Clarkstown. This month the couple and their two daughters, 7 months and 22 months old, moved into what Dr. Cunningham called "truly our dream home" -- a new house on two-and-a-half wooded acres "that feels like it's 100 years old." Some of its fixtures were were taken from old farmhouses. Its price tag was $646,000.
But the best part of the move for them is that they remained close to the shopping and restaurants of Nyack, as well as the 2-million-square-foot Palisades Center Mall in West Nyack, and are still part of the same school district.
"Hardly anyone knows about Valley Cottage," said Dale Lydecker, owner of Lydecker Realty in Nyack. "It's tucked away. Most people find it accidentally when they can't find something in Nyack and then treasure it for its good value, available land and supply of interesting homes, especially along Lake DeForest." The homes range from six Dutch sandstones dating to the 18th century to 1950's ranches and Cape Cods and sprawling new contemporaries.
One of Valley Cottage's first residents was John Ryder, who bought 300 acres of farmland off Kings Highway in 1753. The hamlet takes its name from his Dutch sandstone house, which came to be called "that cottage in the valley." (It is now Dutch House Antiques.)
In 1914, Maurice Heaton, a stained-glass artisan whose work has been exhibited at the Metropolitan Museum of Art and in the Corning Museum of Glass in Corning, N.Y., was a child when he left Switzerland with his parents to settle in Valley Cottage. He lived there until his death in 1990.
In 1939, Alexandra Tolstoy, the youngest daughter of Leo Tolstoy, founded the Tolstoy Foundation with other exiles to minister to the relief of Russian emigres. She lived at the Tolstoy Foundation Center in Valley Cottage until her death in 1979.
Marianne Stewart, owner of the Stewart Professionals real estate agency in Valley Cottage, said that because of the accessibility of Valley Cottage to major highways and shopping malls, including the new Palisades Mall "inventory has been down in Valley Cottage in recent years because anything under $200,000 is scooped up right away."
The Cape Cods and bilevels, which sell for less than $200,000, generally need a lot of work, she said, but "it's hard to beat some of them that come with as many as four bedrooms and two baths on one-half-acre."
FROM there houses jump to $250,000 for larger bilevels built in the late 70's, she said, adding that houses bordering Lake DeForest range from $300,000 to a custom, 3,400-square-foot colonial with lake views that in mid-November was on the market for $585,000.
Anne P. Long, an associate broker at Prudential Rand Realty in New City, said the driving force behind the Valley Cottage real estate market was the eclectic range of homes available.
"You can go from one end of the spectrum to the other in Valley Cottage," she said. "If you want the cute, older house for under $200,000, you can find it. Or, for $225,000 to $295,00, you can buy a Norwegian-inspired home with cut-out hearts and scalloped moldings built by Gustav Svahn. You can buy a new five-bedroom colonial in Joy Acres for the high $300,000's or, you may get lucky and find a Dutch sandstone on a large lot for about $500,000. We have it all."
There are two garden-apartment condominium complexes in Valley Cottage, the 987-unit Mountainview on Sierra Vista Lane and the 350-unit Lake Road condominium complex, both with clubhouses and pools, said Ms. Long.
Some of the units at Mountainview have fireplaces and overlook the Hudson River. Prices range from $75,000 for a one-bedroom to $150,000 for a two-bedroom.
Sixteen condominium town houses are being built at Rockridge Estates on Route 103 where the three-bedroom, two-and-a-half bath homes will sell from $179,000 to $184,900, said Ms. Long.
At the 96-unit Burgundy Gardens off Route 103, rents range from $900 for a one-bedroom to $1,125 for a two-bedroom.
Beyond the wide range of prices for housing is another attraction -- the cultural and socio-economic diversity of the 3,065-student Nyack Public School District, where 59 percent of those enrolled are white, 30.6 percent black, 5.8 percent Asian and American Indian and 4.6 percent Hispanic.
Olga and Mead Stone were living in Westchester for only a year when they moved their family of five to Valley Cottage in 1994. Mrs. Stone, the student activities director at White Plains High School, said that she and her husband, a producer and editor at CBS News, believed that "diversity is important."
"How else can children learn to respect other cultures living in this country," she said. "After all, this country is a mixed salad. America is not a melting pot. I don't want my children to perceive that everyone should have the same ways of doing everything. In a salad, a tomato is a tomato and doesn't taste like a cucumber."
"Over the years we've done a lot of different things to bring our students together," said Roberta R. Zampolin, the Schools Superintendent. "We celebrate each other's culture with International Culture Night where children share their ethnic foods, dance and art. We have an exchange program with Africa, France and Spain. We celebrate everyone's holidays and, beginning in elementary school, we talk about respecting each other, conflict resolution and learning to get along."
In bringing the children together, she said, her staff has also helped them achieve high standards. Of the district's 216 high school graduates last June, 94 percent went on to higher education.
The average S.A.T. scores last June were 497 on the verbal section and 495 on the math section, compared with 495 and 503, respectively, in New York State.
But it's also the district's attention to children's special needs that has made all the difference to the Stones, who live in the original Svahn family home built in the late 1940's. Their youngest daughter, Ana, 8, had speech and language difficulties in the beginning. "I can't applaud the district enough for everything they did for my daughter," Ms. Stone said. "They really believe in early intervention. By third grade, my daughter didn't need special help."
THIS year the district began teaching French and Spanish in the first through fifth grades in all three of the elementary schools. Two of them, the Valley Cottage School and the Liberty School, are in the hamlet and a third is in Upper Nyack. Children attend the Nyack Middle School from grades six through eight.
About 18 percent of the pupils in the district attend parochial or private schools, according to a spokesman for the public school district. Some are enrolled in the Roman Catholic St. Paul's pre-k through grade 8 y school in Valley Cottage, which offers classes for pre-k through eighth grade. Monthly tuition for parishioners of the Congers church is $215 and for nonparishioners, $285.
The houses of worship in the hamlet are the Presbyterian Elim Alliance Church, All Saints Episcopal Church, the Community Bible Church and the Russian Orthodox Church on the Tolstoy Foundation Center property.
Also on the 45-acre property of the center are two adult homes with a total of 42 beds, a 26-cottage retirement village and a 96-bed nursing home, the latter open to all.
Since Valley Cottage is a small town, the library functions as an all-purpose gathering place for residents. Amelia Kalin, program and art exhibit director of the Valley Cottage Library, said two to three times a year the library presents an art and tea program in conjunction with the Metropolitan Museum of Art that offers residents the opportunity to hear a lecture on a current exhibit at the museum. The library also offers cooking programs and a rotating monthly art exhibit by local artists.
For recreation, the residents of the hamlet can fish in Lake DeForest, a reservoir, fly kites and ice skate in the 25-acre Twin Ponds Park or stroll in the passive five-acre Heaton's Park, which has a stream running through it.
Residents can also use Clarkstown's recreational facilities, which include three pools and a dozen parks, said Jo Anne Oldenburger, assistant superintendent of the Department of Recreation and Parks.
Valley Cottage is a small town with but one small strip shopping center, a few fast-food outlets and one pub called Fordy's and no movie house or night life. But it's just right for the Cunningham family.
"I plan on being here a long time, or at least until the kids go on to college," said Dr. Cunningham.

 FROM LIQUOR TO LIBRARY: The 55,000-volume Valley Cottage Library began in 1957 as the Valley Cottage Free Library in a small storefront that was originally a liquor store in the center of the hamlet. Books were donated by the residents and it was staffed by volunteers who, until 1980, closed the building during lunch and dinner. In 1972, the library moved down the block into the site of a 2,000-square-foot former air-conditioning business. The library, now with 18,000 square feet of space, has, in addition to its books, 7,000 books on tape and 1,500 historical photographs. The wooden sign from the original library hangs behind the circulation desk, as a remembrance of times past.

HEADLINE: Baruch Builds An Urban Quadrangle

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP 

 BODY:
FROM a massive base almost a full city block in extent, the facade of the new Baruch College Academic Complex on Lexington Avenue bows outward and tapers inward, as if distorted by some gigantic fish-eye lens, its bare steel columns seeming to curve like bamboo trees under a steady gale.
For the first time in its 79-year history, Baruch has claimed a memorable spot on the New York skyline. 
 Now rising between 24th and 25th Streets, the 17-level Academic Complex, designed by Kohn Pedersen Fox Associates, is remarkable in other ways. With a $270 million price tag, it is the most expensive single building project ever undertaken by the City University of New York. In size, it is second only to the North Academic Center of 1984 at City College in upper Manhattan (and just by a whisker). Baruch's complex is so big that it will represent half the space of the entire campus on completion in 2000.
"On a normal campus," said Emma E. Macari, the vice chancellor of CUNY for facilities planning, construction and management, "we would have done a series of buildings around a quad: a gym, a performing arts center, a business school, liberal arts facilities, a student center with a bookstore and cafeterias. Here, they are all together, in what we call our vertical campus."
Dr. Matthew Goldstein, the president of Adelphi University, who headed Baruch until June, recalled: "It was quite a task to get the Governor to appropriate the money to design and construct the building. Then the problems really began."
A case study in the difficulties of building in New York, the project site included two single-room-occupancy hotels, one with an implacable and outspoken tenant leader; two horse-auction marts and a stable from the early 1900's that were arguably worth landmark designation; a co-op at 330 Third Avenue whose western windows would be blocked by the new building, and up to 30 feet of bedrock, every linear inch of which cost $25,000 to excavate.
To Baruch officials, however, it was the only site that offered an escape from the chronic problem of renting space for $19 million a year in commercial office towers that cannot accommodate 3,000 people getting to class in 20 minutes.
With skip-stop elevator service in six oversized cabs (7 by 12 feet), the new complex can handle such a crowd.
"We kid our alumni that future alumni will no longer have stories about the long wait for elevators," said Dr. Lois S. Cronholm, interim president of the college.
Elevator service will be supplemented with stairways and escalators around a 13-story atrium that has been stepped so that sunlight can penetrate all the way from the south to the north side of the building, even reaching across 25th Street to splash the William and Anita Newman Library.
This staggered arrangement creates a series of smaller spaces within the atrium, a contrast to the vast expanses designed by the architect John Portman in the 1970's.
"The idea was to take a quadrangle and turn it on end," said the architect William Pedersen. "It's one thing to create a Portman-like atrium. But we wanted intimacy. The intention was to break the scale down, so there were plenty of nooks and crannies where people can sit and talk and hang out."
No less interesting on the outside, the complex almost fills the three-dimensional zoning "envelope" that defines what may be built on the site. It recalls the dramatic renderings by Hugh Ferriss in the 1920's that showed structures fully built out according to zoning rules.
To disgruntled neighbors, the structure more vividly recalls the Queen Elizabeth 2. Indeed, there is a certain resemblance to the hull of an ocean liner in drydock.
The 785,000-square-foot complex will enable Baruch to give up 643,000 square feet that it now leases in 111 East 18th Street and 360 Park Avenue South, at 26th Street.
"We have reined in a sprawling campus," Dr. Cronholm said. Clearly, the complex represents an important departure in the physical development of Baruch, known among students as U.C.L.A.: University on the Corner of Lexington Avenue.
B ARUCH has always been regarded for excellence in all areas but one -- our physical facilities," Dr. Cronholm said.
Baruch was founded in 1919 as the City College School of Business and Civic Administration and renamed in 1953 for the financier Bernard M. Baruch, a benefactor of the school. It first occupied the Free Academy at Lexington Avenue and 23d Street, birthplace of City College, which was left behind when C.C.N.Y. moved uptown in 1907.
The academy, built in 1849 in the style of the Gothic town halls of the Netherlands, was replaced by a new School of Business, completed in 1930. It was until now the only structure built especially for the college. All the rest have been hand-me-downs.
The administration building at 135 East 22d Street was originally the Family Court part of Domestic Relations Court, completed in 1940. The future home of the School of Public Affairs, 137 East 22d Street, was originally the Children's Court of 1912.
The library occupies the Lexington Building, 151 East 25th Street, built in 1895 as the power station for the Lexington Avenue cable-car line. It was renovated in 1994 to designs by Davis, Brody & Associates.
Davis, Brody also drew up a proposal in 1986 for "Site B," where the complex is now rising, as part of a master plan.
The site had several advantages. It would be ideally situated between the library and the main core of Baruch buildings. The college already controlled the largest property on the block, a former stable at 155 East 24th Street. And the 10 other parcels were under common ownership -- the estate of Louis Berkowitz, whose L. B. Oil Company operated on the block -- meaning they could be acquired in a single deal.
The 1986 plan envisioned a boxy tower of 23 stories on Lexington Avenue, a mid-block atrium and a 7-story annex.
Dr. Goldstein assumed the presidency of Baruch in 1991. Shopping with his wife at Bloomingdale's a few months later, he gave his credit card to a clerk. "Are you Matthew Goldstein, the president of Baruch?" she asked while filling out the charge form.
"Yes, I am," he answered.
"What are you going to do about those terrible elevators?" she demanded.
That spelled the end to the high-rise approach. Dr. Goldstein's marching orders to the architects two years later called for "a much more horizontal building where we're not hostages to elevators."
The structure descends three levels below ground to accommodate a gymnasium with room for 1,200 spectators, a 25-meter pool, 300-seat theater and 250-seat recital hall. "The key is to get all the high-population stuff as low as possible," Mr. Pedersen said, to cut down elevator demand.
In the upper floors will be the classrooms and faculty offices of the Zicklin School of Business and the Mildred and George Weissman School of Arts and Sciences.
"We are developing essentially a new building type," said Philip Logan, the project coordinator for Baruch.
Space planning and engineering were challenging enough. But there were social and historic complications as well.
East 24th Street was once "Old Stable Row" and many vestiges remained between Lexington and Third Avenues, a block dominated in the early 20th century by Fiss, Doerr & Carroll, which called itself the "largest dealer of horses in the world."
To designs by Horgan & Slattery, architects of the Surrogate's Court on Chambers Street, the company built a seven-story stable and two Beaux-Arts auction marts, one of which was used until 1991 by the H. Kauffman & Sons Saddlery Company.
In a ground-floor studio in the stable building, a young country singer named Elvis Presley recorded his first RCA album in January 1956, including "Blue Suede Shoes" and "One-Sided Love Affair."
If this sounds like a landmark -- it almost was. The Landmarks Preservation Commission considered the Fiss, Doerr buildings in 1989 but failed the next year to muster enough votes for a designation, which would have derailed Baruch's plans.
Jennifer J. Raab, the current chairwoman of the commission, said she "tried to salvage as much of the buildings as possible" for a historic exhibit that is to be incorporated in the north plaza of the new complex.
Far more wrenching was the case of two S.R.O.'s: the Gramercy Hotel on 24th Street and the Amsterdam Hotel on 25th Street. When they were taken over in 1995 by the Dormitory Authority, they had 21 tenants, many of whom were over 50 and living on welfare or Social Security.
Jim Davis, a carpenter and handbag maker who moved into the Gramercy in the early 80's and paid $66 a week for his room, said life grew miserable after the takeover. He said one tenant in the Amsterdam was beaten by a security guard, although officials said that a police investigation failed to substantiate that charge.
Mr. Davis said plumbing and bathroom fixtures were ripped out of vacant units, although officials said the Dormitory Authority repaired electric and water service. Worse yet, Mr. Davis said, was the feeling of isolation as pressure mounted on tenants to move out. About a dozen residents sued the Dormitory Authority. Mr. Davis said the goal was not to stop the project but to win comparable housing at comparable rents in the community, as officials had promised.
ONE by one, however, the other tenants agreed to relocate. They were each paid a $17,500 stipend by the Dormitory Authority. Depending on their needs, they were also given refrigerators or television sets, said Jane R. Crotty, Baruch's director of community relations and economic development. There was a relocation company and social worker on site to assist them.
"Great care was taken in doing the relocation," Ms. Crotty said.
The tenants were dispersed to East Harlem, the Upper West Side and Times Square. "We kept most of them in Manhattan, which is quite a feat," Ms. Crotty said.
Mr. Davis and another tenant would not accept the relocation terms and were evicted in 1996. Now living on West 43d Street, Mr. Davis is pursuing his lawsuit against the Dormitory Authority.
Baruch came under fire from the other side of the block in 1996. The residents of 330 Third Avenue sued to stop the project, saying they were victims of a "bait-and-switch" maneuver, having believed that the new building would be a tower on Lexington Avenue rather than a bulky mid-block structure that walled off their western facade. (While the Academic Complex has only 14 stories above ground, the high floors result in a structure that is almost as tall at its eastern end as the 20-story co-op next door.)
"They misled us in terms of the structure they were going to build," said Ed Virshup, who was then president of the co-op board.
Under a negotiated settlement, Baruch agreed to reconfigure the upper floors somewhat. "What became very important was the light to those western apartments," said Karl F. Schmid, an assistant vice president of Baruch, "and we did give way a bit."
Not enough, however, to mollify Mr. Virshup entirely. He still finds Baruch's building to be "a big monolith that doesn't do anything to enhance the neighborhood because it's not in keeping."
Dr. Cronholm is aware that the neighbors continue to mutter. Her answer: "After our building is built and your property values go up, I think you'll be less unhappy with us."
Ground was broken for the complex in June 1997. And broken. And broken. All told, some 65,000 cubic yards of bedrock -- roughly 140,000 tons -- were excavated, said Nicholas D'Ambrosio, project manager for the Dormitory Authority. The construction manager is TDX Construction Corporation.
The steel work was topped off last month but much remains to be done. What will be the pool is nothing more than a muddy rock pit. No diving will be allowed; the excavation to provide for the right ceiling height would have been prohibitively expensive.
Construction represents $168 million of the $270 million project and is currently running about $1 million under budget, said Anthony J. Mosellie, project manager for Kohn Pedersen Fox. Land acquisition costs are being negotiated, Ms. Crotty said.
Even in a raw state, the complex is already working in one important way. On a recent visit, a patch of sunlight 15 by 20 feet could be seen piercing the atrium and reaching the facade of the library. "Just how we planned it, right?" Mr. D'Ambrosio asked Mr. Pedersen, with evident satisfaction.
Dr. Goldstein said the architects were "artful" in linking the two buildings through the use of light. But something else is on his mind: that frustrated Baruch student who waited on him at Bloomingdale's six years ago. "I wish I could see her today and say, 'We finally did something about those terrible elevators,' " he said.

HEADLINE: ON POLITICS;
Lighting Up With Ideas For Using Tobacco Money

BYLINE: By Jennifer Preston; Jennifer Preston is Trenton bureau chief of The New York Times.

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
The state's first payment does not arrive until April 15, 2000, but the debate has already begun here at the State House over how to spend the state's share of the $206 billion national tobacco settlement.
New Jersey and the 45 other states that have signed the agreement are free to spend the money any way they choose. Negotiators have urged states to spend the money on tobacco-control and tobacco-prevention programs, but that has not stopped some New Jersey lawmakers from suggesting that it could be used to address some of the state's other pressing needs. 
Already, Assembly Minority Leader Joseph V. Doria, a Democrat from Bayonne, suggests that part of the proceeds should be used to help repair the state's crumbling schools.
Under the deal, tobacco companies will begin distributing payments to states, beginning in 2000. New Jersey will get a total of $7.6 billion over 25 years. After the first payment of $100 million in 2000, the state is due to receive annual checks of between $250 million and $325 million until 2025.
Governor Whitman has tried to steer the debate toward using the money for antismoking programs and public health programs, including charity care, which pays hospital bills for the uninsured. "It is very important that we keep our focus on health-related issues," she said. "That's where the money should go, and that's where I want to insure that it continue to go. I would prefer to see it go to things such as that rather than areas that have no necessary relationship to smoking."
But Mrs. Whitman has not yet answered the most important question: Will all of the new money be used to pay for new public health and new antismoking programs or cover the costs of existing programs? And while the original lawsuit, brought by New Jersey and some of the other states, was intended to recover state Medicaid costs from smoking-related diseases, the biggest challenge remains stopping teen-agers from starting to smoke in the first place.
Consider these grim statistics from Len Fishman, the state's health commissioner. One out of five high school students in New Jersey regularly smokes cigarettes. One of out three middle school students has experimented with cigarettes. One out of three teen-agers who starts smoking and continues to smoke will die prematurely from a smoking-related disease.
Mr. Fishman said the tobacco industry was spending about $5 billion a year on marketing and advertising efforts directed at teen-agers, and several hundred million dollars in this market alone.
While New Jersey has imposed new taxes on cigarettes and tough new restrictions limiting cigarette sales to minors, the state now spends about $1 million annually in advertising and marketing efforts to counter the big tobacco companies.
Anyone who knows anything about advertising or even political campaigns knows the power of money in getting your message across. In almost any contest, the campaign that has $100 million to spend is easily going to beat the campaign that has only $1 million.
Some states, including Massachusetts and Minnesota, are already pouring tens of millions of dollars into antismoking campaigns directed at preventing young people from starting smoking and helping others stop. Some antismoking groups think New Jersey should look at what those states have done, and consider adopting similar programs here.
"We should use it for powerful antitobacco advertising, research and comprehensive community programs," said Regina Carlson, executive director and founder of the Group Against Smoking Pollution (GASP). "This is blood money. The tobacco company made this money killing people. We should use it to stop the killing."
While $206 billion is a lot of money, it is much less than the deal that was worked out last spring. But that deal, which provided $368.5 billion and imposed much tougher restrictions on cigarette companies, failed to win Congressional approval.
Now that the states have accepted this pact, it is up to Congress to revisit this issue. Both of New Jersey's Senators, Robert G. Torricelli and Frank R. Lautenberg, have vowed to make this a top priority when the Congress convenes next year.
New Jersey and other states may not be able to regulate nicotine. But there are steps that they can take with this money that might prevent big health care bills in years to come.
State Senator Shirley Turner, a Democrat from Trenton, has offered a solution aimed at preventing diversion of this money for other needs. She noted that while Governor Whitman has proposed using the money for public health care programs, there is nothing to prevent future governors from using it for something else. She has proposed a constitutional amendment that would require all the money coming to New Jersey be spent on public health programs.
"We need only look at the recent raiding of state pension, temporary disablity insurance and unemployment funds as one-time-only gimmicks used to balance the state budget to get a vision of how supposedly dedicated funds can be diverted away from their original purpose to suit a passing political need," Senator Turner said. "Only a constitutional amendment can protect this money for its intended usage."
