HEADLINE: Heart Disease Deaths More Common in Appalachia, Study Finds

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 28

 BODY:
Residents of Appalachia, one of the poorest areas of the country, are more likely to die from heart disease than people living elsewhere, a new study by researchers at West Virginia University has found.
The authors of the 100-page report, "Heart Disease in Appalachia: An Atlas of County Economic Conditions, Mortality and Medical Care Resources," say that a lack of medical facilities throughout the region and a lack of emphasis on good nutrition and exercise contribute to a higher level of heart problems in Appalachia. 
 Elizabeth Barnett, an assistant professor at the West Virginia University school of medicine who led the study group, said researchers found that white Appalachia residents between ages 35 and 64 had a 15 percent to 20 percent greater chance of dying from heart disease than white Americans living elsewhere. Researchers also found that although heart disease deaths declined nationally and in Appalachia, they declined less in Appalachia.
The study found that heart disease death rates among black Appalachia residents, who tend to live in urban areas, especially in Alabama and Mississippi, were closer to national averages.
Ms. Barnett also said that because of Appalachia's poor economic conditions, the sparsely populated communities common to the area are less likely to provide residents recreational facilities and more healthful foods that are routinely available in more densely populated areas.
Ms. Barnett described the report as "a resource to be used to implement programs and policies to prevent heart disease."
"By identifying how the area counties in the area compare to each other, we hope it will be useful to policy makers," she said.
Appalachia sweeps southwest from western New York State deep into the South, to include 399 counties in 13 states. It has historically reflected problems of the rural poor, especially those whose livelihoods come from small family farms and coal mining.
Only in recent years has the region begun to diversify, with many states seeking new industries, like timber, tourism, technology and automobile parts plants.
But many bad physical and nutritional habits persist, leading to coronary disease and death.
Ms. Barnett, who has taught at the university for three years, said the researchers tracked trends in heart disease and cardiac-related deaths from 1980 through 1993.
She said they discovered the highest mortality rates in middle Appalachia -- central West Virginia, eastern Kentucky, western Virginia and northern Tennessee -- a region where coal once ruled but that now suffers from high unemployment, low income and limited availability of medical care.
The research also found that the region lacked resources to aid people who have experienced heart disease and would benefit from exercise and nutritional programs and stress management classes.
"A majority of counties in Appalachia do not have cardiac rehabilitation units or coronary care units," Ms. Barnett said. "Half of all initial heart attacks are fatal, so for those who survive, they still have a high risk for a second one."
The report is scheduled to be published on Monday in the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention's Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report.

HEADLINE: U.S. Bolsters Housing Aid For the Elderly

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 28

 BODY:
With Thanksgiving weekend as a backdrop, President Clinton today highlighted two new housing programs that will provide $822 million for low-income people who are elderly or disabled.
In his weekly radio address, Mr. Clinton said that the money would benefit 29,400 people living in 48 states, and the District of Columbia, Guam and Puerto Rico. Montana and North Dakota, sparsely populated states, are the only two that are not slated to receive any of the money. 
 "For millions of struggling senior citizens and people with disabilities, the peace and security of a decent home is a distant dream and the threat of homelessness an ever-present nightmare," Mr. Clinton said, discussing the programs, which are included in the new budget for the Department of Housing and Urban Development. "Too many of these hard-pressed Americans are warehoused in sterile nursing homes -- not because they need to be, but because they can't afford to live anywhere else."
He added: "Americans should never have to choose between putting a meal on the table or putting a roof over their heads."
The Administration's $25 billion housing budget for the 1999 fiscal year was one of the few appropropriation requests that met with little opposition in the Republican-led Congress this year. It included $1.8 billion in new spending for vouchers, which reflected the first major increase in housing spending in four years and also the department's efforts to rid itself of wasteful programs and mismanagement that characterized it in the past.
The larger of the programs Mr. Clinton cited in his radio address generates $696 million in grants to nonprofit organizations around the country to build and rehabilitate 8,200 apartment units for older people and the disabled who fall below certain income levels.
The second program will provide an additional $126.8 million to be distributed among disabled people in the form of rent subsidies.
Administration officials predict that the new apartments will accommodate 12,400 people through projects managed by 166 private groups that competed for the grants. The money will cover development costs and does not have to be repaid so long as the new housing is available for 40 years to low-income elderly residents or people with disabilities.
More money is available to the project owner to cover differences between the rent and operating costs.
Those receiving the assistance must be classified as "very low income," which means that a household cannot earn more than 50 percent of the area's median income. On a national average, Administration officials say that amounts to less than $8,000 a year.
The second program is expected to provide affordable housing for more than 17,000 low-income people with disabilities so that their rent does not exceed 30 percent of their income.
"This is going to be a priority for the President," Andrew M. Cuomo, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, said in an interview.
"We're all getting older, not only individually, but as a society, and the numbers are alarming," Mr. Cuomo said. "The graying of America is going to have significant impact on the nation's housing and will be one of the greatest challenges we face over the next 10 years."
Currently, the country has about 34 million citizens 65 or older, compared with about 3 million at the turn of the 20th century. Mr. Cuomo said that the figure is expected to reach 53 million within 25 years, putting additional strain on the need for affordable units.
As a result, Mr. Cuomo said, the department and the private organizations that are building new units are redesigning them with older and disabled people in mind, focusing on communal facilities for health and recreation.
Mr. Clinton said that despite the benefits most Americans are accruing through the prosperous economy, too many elderly and disabled people "are trapped in substandard housing, where broken plumbing, inadequate heat and hazardous hallways are a dangerous fact of life. And too many spend more than half of their modest incomes on housing, often sacrificing basic needs like food and medical care just to pay the rent."
Promoting the Administration's efforts, he added, "At this moment of unparalleled prosperity, we must not do less."

HEADLINE: UNREGULATED CASH FLOWS INTO HANDS OF P.A.C.'S FOR 2000

BYLINE: By JILL ABRAMSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 28

 BODY:
Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska is engaged in the first test of the 2000 Presidential campaign: proving his ability to raise money. Like other Democratic and Republican hopefuls, he will have to raise more money than ever, at least $22 million, and earlier than ever before.
Searching for creative ways to get donations much larger than those allowed by the strict limits of Federal election laws, Senator Kerrey and six other Presidential aspirants have turned to so-called soft money. To raise these large unrestricted contributions from wealthy individuals, corporations and labor unions, they are exploiting the less-restrictive political donation regulations at the state level, establishing nonprofit organizations and setting up political action committees. 
 Soft money is bleeding into the Presidential campaign earlier than ever before and spreading among more potential candidates. And these controversial big donations are being solicited directly by the potential candidates for their own political committees, while in the past soft money was funneled through the national political parties.
The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1974, passed after Watergate to prohibit large, special interest contributions, limits donations to Presidential primary candidates to $1,000. But there are many legal ways for aspiring candidates to skirt that limit.
Mr. Kerrey's fund-raising device, for example, is a political action committee that is allowed to raise larger soft money contributions. Next month, many of Senator Kerrey's most generous financial backers plan to gather at Omaha's Boys Town, where his political action committee, Building America's Conscience and Kids P.A.C., is sponsoring an international economic conference. Most of them have already given to this committee, which has raised $1.2 million.
Among those expected to attend are Kerrey supporters like the Baltimore Orioles owner, Peter Angelos, and the Wall Street investor Barry Wigmore, who have each already donated $25,000 to the political action committee, established in June. They can give these larger sums because Senator Kerrey's committee is set up with both Federal and non-Federal accounts as allowed by law. The non-Federal account can accept unlimited contributions. In fact, the committee has raised almost $800,000 through its non-Federal account.
Without this soft money, it is unlikely that Senator Kerrey or other Presidential hopefuls considering the race could raise $50,000 a day between now and the selection of the first delegates in early 2000. This amount is necessary to reach the minimum of $22 million that several campaign experts estimate candidates would need to be competitive.
"It's a staggering sum," said Steve Jarding, the Senator's national political director. "But Bob believes he could raise the money if he ran."
Until now, the political parties have been the main fund-raising vehicles for these large donations. In 1996, soft money contributions to the Democratic National Committee became a source of controversy when millions of dollars from the party were used to pay for early advertising for the Clinton-Gore ticket.
Like Senator Kerrey, at least five Republican Presidential hopefuls have established state-level political committees. Ostensibly, these committees are meant to support local candidates. Senator Kerrey, for example, has used his to make campaign donations to local Democratic candidates, including $85,000 sent to New Hampshire, the site of the first Presidential primary. But the state committees are also being used by the aspirants to pay for big-ticket items, like travel, staff and even more fund-raising for their incipient national campaigns. And these committees are not the only devices the candidates are using to raise unlimited contributions.
The wealthy publisher Steve Forbes has also established a nonprofit organization, Americans for Hope Growth and Opportunity, that is raising unrestricted contributions. Mr. Forbes, who ran unsuccessfully for the Republican Presidential nomination in 1996, himself gave $100,000 and the organization has raised more than $13 million from 140,000 donors, said Bill Dal Col, the group's president.
While Mr. Dal Col said the organization supported issues, not candidates, the issues championed by Americans for Hope Growth and Opportunity are the ones Mr. Forbes embraced in 1996, including tax cuts and school choice.
Campaign finance experts say the big presence of soft money so early in the Presidential election season is further evidence of the erosion of the post-Watergate election law reforms.
Starting in 1988, the two political parties began gutting the Federal limits by soliciting soft money donations, which are unlimited but are supposed to be used only for generic party-building activities.
This year, both parties used soft money to pay for issue advertising in the Congressional elections. According to pre-election reports filed at the Federal Election Commission, soft money contributions to Republican Party committees grew 144 percent over the last midterm elections, while Democratic soft money totals increased 84 percent. Together, the two parties raked in $173 million in soft money. The commission is considering a proposal to ban soft money.
Today, soft money is already bleeding into the Presidential primary contests because the primaries are front-loaded in 2000, with many big states, including California and New York, expected to choose delegates before early March.
Terry McAuliffe, a leading Democratic fund-raiser, said the schedule of early primaries, including regional contests in the South, New England and the Rocky Mountain states, would have a profound effect on fund-raising in 2000. "The way this primary schedule has been designed there is no Presidential fund-raising strategy that allows you to raise money in 2000," he said in an interview. "It must all be raised in 1999."
Mr. McAuliffe said this would create a more closed contest because an outsider candidate would not have time to exploit a surprise win to raise money, as George Bush did in 1980 after winning the Iowa caucuses.
Money spent in this early stage by Presidential aspirants does not count against the spending limit set for Presidential primary candidates who accept Federal matching funds. In 1996, the amount was $37 million and is expected to be about $45 million in 2000. Once their candidacy is declared, Presidential contenders can no longer be affiliated with political action committees and must limit their contributions from individuals to $1,000. (Mr. Forbes did not accept matching funds in 1996 and spent $30 million of his own money. In 2000, if he runs, Mr. Dal Col said Mr. Forbes would not spend as much of his own money, but would not accept matching funds.)
Until they become declared candidates, Presidential aspirants can continue to solicit soft money for their state-level political action committees without worrying about complying with more rigid Federal rules. Most of these committees have been set up in states with the least restrictive election laws. Virginia, which permits unlimited contributions from both individuals and corporations, has been a popular site for political action committees connected to the 2000 Presidential aspirants.
"Virginia has become the Cayman Islands of Presidential fund-raising," said Larry Makinson, executive director of the Center for Responsive Politics, a Washington research group that tracks contributions. Five Republicans, former Vice President Dan Quayle, the conservative leader Gary Bauer, former Gov. Lamar Alexander of Tennessee, the former Vice Presidential nominee Jack F. Kemp and Senator John Ashcroft of Missouri have political action committees in Virginia. Although the Republican leaders have used some of their Virginia money to back local candidates, most of it has not been spent in the Old Dominion.
Not all would-be 2000 candidates have state political action committees. Vice President Al Gore and former Senator Bill Bradley, Democrat of New Jersey, both have only Federal P.A.C.'s. Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, a Republican who is a potential candidate for President, has yet to establish such a committee. Senator John Kerry, a Massachusetts Democrat who has spurned political action committee money for most of his career, is considering setting up such a committee as he explores whether to run for the Democratic Presidential nomination.
The early front-runners, like the Vice President and the Texas Governor, may not need to use state committees. Both have national fund-raising networks and can raise money quickly. Mr. Gore has been a fund-raising star for the Democratic National Committee. Governor Bush will have easy access to wealthy Texas donors and his father's old money machine. Last summer, Mr. Bush raised more than $1 million in Washington for his re-election campaign at a fund-raising dinner organized by some of former President Bush's longtime supporters.
Senator Kerrey, who has headed the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee, and the minority House leader, Richard A. Gephardt, also have national fund-raising networks, although theirs are not as formidable as Mr. Gore's.
On the Republican side, Mr. Alexander, who pioneered the use of state political action committees and soft money and made an unsuccessful bid for the Republican nomination in 1996, has proven to be a prodigious early fund-raiser. Mr. Bauer has raised millions nationally through the mail. And Mr. Forbes is in a class of his own.
Both Mr. Alexander and Mr. Forbes have already spent large sums on advertisements in early primary states like New Hampshire.

HEADLINE: His Home's a Castle, With a Dragon of Sorts

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

 BODY:
BEDFORD, N.Y., Nov. 27
Darlington Castle was like a lover Donald A. Lehman thought he could change: He coveted it despite its obvious flaw.
The elegant turn-of-the-century stone mansion, with its long, winding drive, oak-paneled drawing rooms and view clear to the World Trade Center, seems to sit on the top of the earth. But the castle also has a working radio tower mounted on its roof and an iron-clad lease that insures it will remain there until 2006. 
 Mr. Lehman, who owns an alarm company, and his wife, Barbara, a retired chemistry teacher, bought Darlington Castle and more than 30 acres of hillside for $1.5 million in 1993, substantially less than similar houses in the area cost. In this town of old money, new celebrity and sprawling estates 40 miles north of midtown Manhattan, there were few other takers for a house with a 20-foot antenna that broadcasts 1,500 watts of "smooth jazz" 24 hours a day to northern Westchester.
"All I could think about was the house," said Mr. Lehman, who first visited it in 1983 when he tried to sell the previous owners an alarm from his company, Attack Cat Security. "It was my dream house. The minute I saw it, I said, 'I want this house.' "
Although the Lehmans knew what they were getting into, they now complain that Kenny G has become the soundtrack to their lives and that the station, WZZN at 106.3 FM, comes through on every channel on the radio dial, meddles with their television reception, interrupts their fax machine and interferes with their business equipment. Mr. Lehman attributes his headaches to microwave radiation from the tower and the couple say the tower is ill-maintained, causing their roof to leak and bathroom ceiling to collapse.
The station's owners see things differently. "His claims range from false to largely exaggerated," said Robert F. Davis, the lawyer for WZZN, which is owned by Westchester Radio L.L.C.
"Our client, to buy some peace, has made many offers to accommodate him," Mr. Davis said. The station has installed cable television in 5 of the house's 17 rooms and pays the bill for the service (about $100 a month). The station has given the Lehmans two interference-free radios, two digital answering machines and offered to pay half the cost of a new roof. The station is obligated to pay about $5,000 a year in rent. It has offered to increase the rent to $18,000, Mr. Davis said, and to install cable television in the three-bedroom pool house. "And by the way," Mr. Davis said, "he paid $1.5 million for a house that's probably worth 6 or 7 million."
Yet the Lehmans are determined to be rid of the antenna.
They have been arrested once for tampering with the transmitting equipment. They have paid a $12,000 settlement to the radio company and lost two court cases and an appeal to the Federal Communications Commission to get rid of the antenna. A State Supreme Court judge issued an injunction this summer to prevent them from touching the equipment. They have been through four sets of lawyers; the last ones resigned a few weeks ago, after the Lehmans let it be known that they planned to tear the antenna down.
"I'll represent myself," Mr. Lehman said. "I'm doing it my way. It's time to have a Boston Tea Party."
The battle seems to be just another chapter in their home's colorful history. Charles F. Darlington Jr., an economist and diplomat whose father built Darlington Castle in 1904, fell upon hard times in 1966. Neighbors say he lost all his money in a bad investment. To generate enough income to keep the drafty castle in the family, he sold property and granted a 40-year lease to Martin Stone for the tower.
Mr. Stone, who died in June, was the producer of "Howdy Doody" and a pioneer in community radio. A lawyer by training, he drafted a lease that has remained valid even though the castle has changed ownership twice and the radio station has changed ownership four times. "It was a lease that was so one-sided that no one but a desperate man would sign it," Mr. Lehman said.
It turned the house into a white elephant.
"A lot of buyers came to see it but nobody wanted that house," said Sally Siano, a real estate agent in Bedford Hills who remembered when the house went on the market in the early 1990's for more than $5 million. "Every client I ever brought there would not even consider living in it because of the electric fields and their concern for their health," she said.
Joy Schieffelin and her late husband, William Jay Schieffelin 3d, a wine and spirit importer, bought Darlington Castle in 1975. Like Mr. Lehman, Mr. Schieffelin was enamored with the castle and its views. All the static that came through their television, radios and stereo could not persuade Mr. Schieffelin to move, his wife said, though she was never comfortable there.
"The lease was absolutely tight," Mrs. Schieffelin said sadly. "There was nothing we could do about it. I don't know why we stayed there except my husband loved that castle."
Mrs. Schieffelin was friendly with Mr. Lehman, who regularly serviced her security alarm. She knew how much Mr. Lehman wanted the house and said that she warned him before he bought the property that the lease was unbreakable.
"He said, 'Don't worry, I'll get rid of that antenna,' " Mrs. Schieffelin recalled in a telephone conversation. "I said, 'No, you won't.' and he said, 'Oh yes, I will.' "

GRAPHIC: Photo: Donald A. Lehman bought Darlington Castle, his "dream house," in Bedford, despite the radio tower protruding from the roof. (Joyce Dopkeen/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: In Albany, Quiet Clamor For a Raise

BYLINE: By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ 

 BODY:
With the cheery distractions of the holiday season at hand and even the most dedicated lobbyists paying scant attention to the business of state government, what better time for New York State lawmakers to take up an issue that has long inflamed voters -- legislative pay raises.
So goes the thinking in Albany, where some members of the Legislature, crying something akin to poverty, plead with their leaders to convene an unusual end-of-year legislative session to push through their first raise in 10 years. 
 The 211 members of the Legislature are to return to the State Capitol early this week, ostensibly to elect leaders for the 1999 legislative session. But as long as they are in town, there is also the chance that they will take up the matter of increasing their pay from the current base of $57,500 a year.
"We have been told to be in Albany on Monday to re-elect our majority leader, but we were also told to be prepared to stay longer if necessary," said Nicholas A. Spano of Yonkers, a deputy majority leader in the Republican-controlled Senate. "We weren't given any specifics. But obviously the thing that is high on the minds of most legislators is a cost-of-living adjustment."
If state lawmakers decide to approve a pay raise for themselves -- possibly along with raises for judges, agency heads and senior aides to the Governor -- they would have to act swiftly. State law prohibits a sitting Legislature from giving itself a salary increase that takes effect during its current two-year term. To get a raise in 1999, lawmakers must adopt legislation before Jan. 1, when a new two-year term of the Legislature begins, with newly elected members.
Even though rank-and-file members have clamored for a pay raise and legislative leaders have spoken privately about the matter with the Governor, no formal proposal has been drawn up.
That said, some ranking members of the Legislature have set their sights on a pay raise of at least $20,000 a year, or nearly 35 percent, for a job that the State Constitution envisions as part time, but has in fact become nearly a yearlong commitment for lawmakers in recent years. The session is supposed to run from January to June, but unresolved issues -- usually the budget -- can tether legislators to Albany far longer. The 220th session, which ended on Aug. 10, 1997, was the longest ever, lasting 210 days.
For now, the big question on the minds of most lawmakers is how to give themselves a pay raise without stirring the ire of a public that has become increasingly frustrated with the Legislature's long record of partisan gridlock, late budgets and squandered opportunities.
The matter is so incendiary that lawmakers, almost to a person, make a point of saying that they are not in fact seeking a pay raise but rather a "cost-of-living adjustment."
"It is almost impossible to discuss this issue as a legitimate policy question," complained Richard L. Brodsky, a Democratic Assemblyman from Westchester. "There are forces out there who want to define this issue in purely political terms, and that's unfair."
He continued, "You ought to be able to decide whether it's justified to go 10 years without a cost-of-living adjustment and what level of compensation is appropriate. But it's been difficult to get those questions asked in a thoughtful way."
New York State's annual legislative pay base of $57,500 is less than the base pay for New York City Council members, who make $70,500 a year, but second in state governments only to California's base of $75,600. Lawmakers in Albany also receive stipends for leadership positions, like committee chairmanships, which can add greatly to their income -- from $6,500 for a ranking minority member of a committee, to $30,000 for the leaders of both chambers, the Speaker of the Assembly and the majority leader of the Senate.
As they have in previous years, lawmakers this year have found themselves vexed by the pay raise issue for one main reason: just about everybody wants one, but few dare to speak openly about it, lest they appear greedy and self-serving. But privately, many of them, especially those from New York City and its suburbs, say that they are barely able to make ends meet in a job that takes up more and more of their time.
Beyond that, state lawmakers routinely complain that many county and city legislators are paid more than they are. They note that the demands on the Legislature have grown in recent years, particularly as the Federal Government has placed new responsibilities on states, like the overhaul of the welfare system.
The New York Legislature was established in 1777, and its members for years received no compensation. The first paychecks for state legislators were in 1821, when voters approved a salary of $3 a day. It was left to voters to approve raises until 1948, when the State Constitution was amended to grant the legislators, with the Governor's approval, the power to set their pay. Since then, the Legislature has had eight raises, bringing their salaries from $5,000 a year to the current $57,500.
In the past, state lawmakers put off addressing the touchy issue until that legislative twilight period between the November elections, after which they are secure in their seats for another two years, and the Jan. 1 deadline that opens a new two-year legislative term.
Because incumbents almost always hold on to their seats in New York -- no member who sought re-election lost in the recent November elections, for example -- that approach provides them the opportunity to give themselves a raise for the next legislative term without having to worry about facing voters until two years later.
But as in years past, lawmakers face another hurdle this time around: getting support from Gov. George E. Pataki for a pay raise even before such a measure is brought to the floor of the Legislature for a vote. That support is crucial because neither house wants to give the Governor the opportunity to veto such a bill and thereby bolster his standing among voters at the political expense of lawmakers.
The strongest leadership voice for a raise comes from the Democratic Speaker of the Assembly, Sheldon Silver, who recently said he vigorously supported an increase. The Republican majority leader of the Senate, Joseph L. Bruno, has strongly suggested that he does not believe that lawmakers make enough money .
But it is still far from clear whether the issue will be taken up when lawmakers convene in Albany for their leadership meetings, and that is in large part due to the Governor, who, legislators say, has sent mixed signals about his position. His spokeswoman, Zenia Mucha, did not return a phone call last week seeking comment on the issue.
There is widespread speculation among lawmakers that Mr. Pataki is seeking to force his Democratic rivals in the Legislature to pass legislation that he supports -- such as a bill that would create privately run but publicly financed charter schools -- in exchange for his pledge to sign a pay raise bill.
But should Mr. Pataki pursue such a strategy, he may face resistance from Democrats, who, publicly anyway, say that the Governor should not be linking a pay bill to unrelated pieces of legislation.

HEADLINE: Purges Hint at Beginning of the End for Milosevic

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Serbia, Nov. 26

 BODY:
In moves viewed here and by some in Washington as signs of weakness rather than strength, President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia has conducted an extraordinary purge of his innermost circle, dismissing the leaders of the army, the air force and the intelligence service, as well as one of his most trusted political commissars.
Few are brave enough to say how or when Mr. Milosevic, the strongman of Serbia, will go. But many officials here and in Washington agree that the dismissals represent the beginning of the end. 
 The purge, conducted in the wake of Mr. Milosevic's agreement on Oct. 13 to pull troops out of Kosovo, culminated this week with the dismissal of Gen. Momcilo Perisic, the long-serving Army Chief of Staff and an architect of the war in Bosnia.
In the last month Mr. Milosevic has been seen by former associates as increasingly insecure, even paranoid, as Kosovo drifts from his control, the enfeebled economy gets weaker and he bows to the demands of his politically powerful wife, replacing his apparatchiks with hers.
"Deep in their minds they know that there will be social unrest and they want totally loyal people around them when it happens," Bratislav Grubacic, the editor of an English-language newsletter for diplomats and others in Belgrade, said of Mr. Milosevic and his wife, Mirjana Markovic. "He is closing the areas where he doesn't feel comfortable -- people in the state apparatus who might eventually become disloyal."
A Washington official who has followed Yugoslavia for more than a decade said: "The regime is brittle. It will crack. It will break."
The dismissals have inspired open talk here of the resemblance between the ruling court of Mr. Milosevic, his wife and their two wealthy children, Marko and Marija, and that of the Ceausescu family in Romania, which was dominated by a husband-and-wife team and collapsed in a bloody downfall in 1989.
The fall of Mr. Milosevic would have important consequences for the United States. Mr. Milosevic has been treated by the Clinton Administration as an important keeper of the peace in Bosnia, where American troops are based, and as a negotiating partner over the future of Kosovo, where the ethnic Albanian majority is seeking independence.
Mr. Milosevic rules from behind closed doors, rarely appearing in public and almost never granting interviews, even to Serbian state news media, which he controls. There has been no official explanation of the recent dismissals.
The purges began on the heels of the departure from Belgrade of the American envoy, Richard C. Holbrooke, who persuaded Mr. Milosevic to agree to international observers in Kosovo, and were preceded by the closing of independent newspapers and academic dismissals at Belgrade University.
The removal of General Perisic on Tuesday was perhaps the least surprising, after he publicly criticized Mr. Milosevic last month for allowing what is left of Yugoslavia to become a pariah state. Yugoslavia now consists of two republics: dominant Serbia and smaller Montenegro.
General Perisic, who led the Yugoslav National Army during the atrocities in Bosnia, was reported to have opposed the use of his soldiers against ethnic Albanian civilians in Kosovo during the summer offensive there. His skepticism apparently infuriated Ms. Markovic.
The agreement on Kosovo between Serbia and NATO was signed by General Perisic, thus forcing Mr. Milosevic to wait a decent interval before getting rid of him. What was surprising was General Perisic's decision to fight back.
On Thursday night the general taunted Mr. Milosevic with a statement saying he had been dismissed illegally and hinting that he was prepared to lead Yugoslavia down a different path.
"I was replaced without consultations, in an inadequate and illegal way," the general said in his statement, which was issued through an independent news agency. "This establishment does not like officials with high personal integrity who use their own heads. I am still at the disposal of the army, the people and the state."
General Perisic, a native of Montenegro, is reported to have the backing of that republic's president, Milo Djukanovic, a former Milosevic ally who has turned against him and has won American support for his stand.
Some opponents of Mr. Milosevic, who has thrived throughout his 11-year rule by fomenting crises, fear that with Kosovo effectively now policed by the West and its ethnic Albanian guerrillas lying low in winter snows, he will use the lull to provoke a confrontation with Montenegro.
General Perisic was replaced by Gen. Dragoljub Ojdanic, a member of Ms. Markovic's political party who was commander of one of the army corps most active in the savage 1991 fight to wrest the city of Vukovar from the Croatians, officials said.
The first senior official to be removed was Jovica Stanisic, the head of state security services, whom the West considers a clever intelligence officer. Mr. Stanisic, who knows all the worst secrets of Mr. Milosevic's rule, was replaced by a senior police patrol officer, Rade Markovic, a loyalist of Ms. Markovic and a member of her party, known as the Yugoslav Left. Mr. Markovic is not related to Ms. Markovic.
Along with Mr. Stanisic, a dozen top operational officers of the security service were forced into retirement or removed, a move that may undermine Mr. Milosevic in the longer term, officials said.
Mr. Milosevic next dismissed Milorad Vucelic, the deputy leader of Mr. Milosevic's Socialist Party, who served as the President's political disciplinarian.
To complete the list, the head of the air force, Gen. Ljubisa Velickovic, who protested Mr. Milosevic's agreement to allow NATO surveillance flights over Kosovo, was also removed.
Mr. Milosevic has carried out purges before, but never to this extent. And he has never so obviously filled vacancies with loyalists of his wife.
This round is also different because it comes when there is no obvious danger to Mr. Milosevic; the Serbian opposition, which mounted vast months-long demonstrations two years ago, is weak and divided. And for the first time even courtiers of his rule speak of it in scathing terms.
Slavko Curuvija, the editor in chief of the Daily Telegraf and European magazine, which were closed down by the Government last month, was until recently a confidant of Ms. Markovic.
But in an interview, he described how he went to see her in October to tell her a few home truths. "In the next year or next two years they will lose power," Mr. Curuvija said. "They are making a private regime in which nobody who is not a close friend or not a bodyguard has important positions in the Government."
He said his meeting with Ms. Markovic ended abruptly. "I told her that everything her husband had done was dramatically bad and that he had to do several things to save Serbia," he said. "I said: 'If you don't stop what's going on, the end will be bloody,' and that many people will be killed and maybe some will be hanged on the Terazije," a central square in Belgrade.
Mr. Curuvija said the outlook for the Government was very grim indeed. "If you make war in Slovenia, you can step back to Croatia," he said, referring to Mr. Milosevic's first fights within the old Yugoslavia. "If you start a war in Montenegro, you can step back to Belgrade. When you start a war in Belgrade, you have nowhere to step back to except a trench around your house."
A critical factor governing how long the Government will survive is the economy, which has been battered by sanctions and bans on loans from the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund, and continues its relentless decline.
But so far Mr. Milosevic has managed to manipulate the currency so that he can pay about three-quarters of the annual state pensions due, and keep the police and army paid. And with help from Russia, which provides natural gas even though Serbia is late in its payments, and with deals like a recent oil purchase from Libya, Mr. Milosevic is able to provide energy for the long-suffering people.
"Don't underestimate his ability to scrape the bottom for economic deals," said a Western diplomat.
Aleksandar Tijanic, a former Minister of Information, said he believes that the Government has $1 billion to $2 billion stashed abroad that it can draw on. "It's an enormous amount of money in this situation," he said.
There is considerable division among former members of the Milosevic circle and Western officials who expect Mr. Milosevic to fall about how he will go.
"I don't think it will be a palace coup," said the Washington official. "It's going to be in the streets. It could develop rapidly, something we won't anticipate -- say, superinflation should return and dinars in the morning can't buy bread in the afternoon."
In Mr. Grubacic's view, "No one can see him going from power normally. Something will happen next year for sure. Things are going quickly."
One sign of the times is that the new leader of the opposition coalition that organized the street demonstrations two years ago is Nebojsa Covic. Back then, he was Mayor of Belgrade and a close associate of Mr. Milosevic.
Mr. Covic, who describes in vivid detail Mr. Milosevic's style of bawling out underlings -- "He yelled at me that I was a coward" -- acknowledged that the opposition remains weak.
But he said that eventually, he cannot say exactly when, a spark would come from the streets. Then, as happened in Romania, it would be a matter of which way the mainstay of Mr. Milosevic's power, the 90,000-member police force, would go.
"The police are more and more willing to go against him every day," Mr. Covic said. "But they want to make sure they are on the winning side."

HEADLINE: A Fan's Fan, but an Owner First;
Decision on Patriots Put Economics Ahead of Emotions

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HALBFINGER 

 BODY:
The occasion called for Champagne.
Robert K. Kraft, the owner of the New England Patriots, had just agreed to move his football team from Massachusetts to Connecticut. The Governor there was promising to build him a $350 million stadium in Hartford, to guarantee up to $17.5 million a year in sales of luxury seats, to let him keep all stadium profits without paying any rent, even to pick up the tab for the insurance. All in all, the experts said, it was one of the richest stadium deals any sports mogul had negotiated. 
 But last Sunday, Mr. Kraft wasn't celebrating. In full-page advertisements in the Boston newspapers, Mr. Kraft offered a 1,400-word apology. "Make no mistake," he wrote. "This decision was not easy."
Mr. Kraft doesn't just want Connecticut's money. He wants to be forgiven for taking it.
Perhaps more than any other sports team owner in America, Mr. Kraft, 57, embodies the opposing impulses -- one economic, the other emotional -- that are throwing dozens of cities into spasms of subsidized stadium construction and leaving others, deserted by their teams, perhaps wishing they had.
Like many of his peers, particularly in the National Football League, Mr. Kraft sought the greater revenue that a new stadium would bring from expanded luxury seating, concessions and advertising. But unlike many of them, Mr. Kraft, a native of Boston and a loyal season ticketholder before he bought the team, was loath to use explicit threats of leaving his home state as a ploy in the negotiations with Massachusetts, even as the talks about the state's contribution for a new stadium grew increasingly bitter.
When he finally acted, it was after five years of struggle with a State Legislature whose leaders came to consider him little more than a "whiny millionaire" who simply wanted too big a handout.
In its deal to build a new stadium, Hartford is buying more than just a competitive N.F.L. team and a palatial new sports complex: in Mr. Kraft, the Connecticut capital is getting someone who is described as a ruthless businessman but who also requires his players to make 10 appearances a season at local charities and civic groups. He is a man who also pays for parks in Israel and library wings in Worcester, Mass., and writes half-million-dollar checks to his own favorite causes, from the Boys and Girls Clubs of Boston to cancer research and domestic-violence prevention.
But above all, Hartford's newest corporate citizen is a team owner who is deeply and openly emotional about his relationship with Patriot fans: two seasons ago, as the team's fortunes soared with a trip to the Super Bowl, that bond became an out-and-out lovefest. Before home games, Mr. Kraft would cruise through the parking lots outside suburban Foxboro Stadium in a golf cart, high-fiving tailgaters, unashamedly reveling in their affection. And each time the Patriots scored, he would wave down from his luxury suite above the 50-yard line, and the crowd would roar back.
Things have changed in the past week.
On Nov. 19, hours after he announced his deal for a Hartford stadium, a photograph of the absent Mr. Kraft was flashed on a banquet hall screen as the American Ireland Fund honored its largest contributors. The black-tie crowd of 1,500 booed loudly. On Monday night, there were few signs of rancor at Foxboro during the Patriots' game against the Miami Dolphins, suggesting that Patriot fans viewed his decision less harshly than the columnists and radio hosts who had demonized him. But Mr. Kraft skipped the golf-cart ride nonetheless.
"I don't think he'll be ostracized," said Stephen Tocco, the president of a Boston consulting firm, who worked closely with Mr. Kraft as an aide to former Gov. William F. Weld. "But he won't be signing many autographs anymore. His worst moment is going to be the day the trucks leave. But he's got three years to get ready for that day."
Mr. Kraft declined repeated requests for an interview. His son Jonathan, the Patriots' vice president, explained that more publicity could only jeopardize legislative approval of the stadium in Hartford: "We want to stay underground for now," he said.
Clearly, Mr. Kraft has encountered far fewer difficulties in Connecticut than in Massachusetts. In Boston, he was often criticized for the heavy-handed tactics he used to pursue a stadium deal. But beneath the surface were old Boston tensions seldom discussed openly. "This town is not impressed with new money," said one longtime supporter, trying to explain Mr. Kraft's troubles.
Others, including people who know him well, said there was a deeper source to the vehemence of opposition to his proposals, suggesting that although Mr. Kraft grew up in a Jewish community in Brookline and saw himself as having deep roots in Boston, to the Irish, Italian and Brahmin insiders with whom he was dealing he remained an outsider, first and foremost.
Mr. Kraft spent more than a year on an ill-fated plan for a stadium in South Boston -- an insular, predominantly Irish neighborhood notorious for its battles against school busing in the 1970's. Residents, perceiving that he was trying to ram the project down their throats, rebelled.
"I don't know if it's anti-Semitism, or anti-Kraftism, or anti-footballism, but it's really strange," Jonathan Kraft told The Boston Globe in February 1997, trying to account for the enmity his father had stirred up in South Boston. "I just don't get it."
Robert Kraft's love of sports began young, but was frustrated early on. His home in Brookline was a few blocks from the old Braves Field, where he sold programs until the baseball team moved to Milwaukee in 1953.
His father was a dry-goods merchant who was better known as a lay leader at an Orthodox synagogue. But the family's religious observance interfered with the teen-ager's desire to play high school sports, with games on Saturday. He played football for the first time as an undergraduate at Columbia University, excelling in an intercollegiate league for lightweight athletes.
After Harvard Business School he married Myra Hiatt, the daughter of a wealthy Worcester manufacturer, and soon went to work for his father-in-law. In 1972, the year he first bought season tickets to the Patriots, Mr. Kraft, then 31, took control of his father-in-law's packaging corporation, Rand-Whitney, and launched International Forest Products, which trades in raw materials around the world. Today, the two comprise the largest privately owned packaging company in the country and the biggest but least-noticed divisions of the Kraft Group, which generates an estimated $500 million a year in revenues.
 
Leaving Obscurity By Buying a Team
 Yet, outside the Boston charity-dinner circuit, Mr. Kraft was still virtually unknown when he bought the Patriots in 1994.
It was not his first venture into professional sports; he had owned the Boston Lobsters, a World Team Tennis franchise, until that league folded in 1978. Later, he made passes at the Red Sox and Celtics, and twice tried unsuccessfully to buy the Patriots, before seizing on an alternate route to control of the team -- becoming its landlord. In 1988, he and a Massachusetts shopping mall developer, Stephen Karp, bought Foxboro Stadium, the Patriots' current home 30 miles south of Boston, at a bankruptcy sale for $25 million.
Six years later, Mr. Kraft, fresh from buying out Mr. Karp's interest in the stadium, used his control of the Patriots' lease to edge out several rival bidders for the team. The closest competition came from a St. Louis businessman who offered $200 million and would have moved the team there. Mr. Kraft paid only $158 million because he threatened a costly legal battle if another buyer tried to break the Foxboro lease.
"That was far more than he wanted to pay," Mr. Tocco said. "But he really believes in Boston and Massachusetts, and the Patriots looked like they were leaving."
At the time, Mr. Kraft was hailed as the team's savior. He cultivated the image of a fan's fan, recalling in interviews how he and his sons had endured the lean years alongside blue-collar Patriots fans and wanted nothing more as owners than to bring a championship home to New England.
Almost immediately, however, Mr. Kraft began pushing for a new stadium to replace Foxboro. And Mr. Kraft, the fan's fan, increasingly clashed with the fan's favorite, Coach Bill Parcells, over player decisions. Mr. Parcells, who led the team to the Super Bowl in January 1997, resigned soon after the Patriots' loss.
Meanwhile, Mr. Kraft brought his business acumen and his history as a football fan to bear in his dealings with other N.F.L. owners, earning respect as a consensus builder. Having owned a Boston television station for five years, Mr. Kraft played an important role in negotiating the league's eight-year, $18 billion television rights deal with CBS, Fox, ABC and ESPN.
Pat Bowlen, the owner of the Denver Broncos and chairman of the league's broadcast committee, said that Mr. Kraft had stressed the need to continue broadcasting N.F.L. games over free television. "There was plenty of talk about going in different directions," he said. "But Bob felt over-the-air was necessary for an ongoing, stable relationship with our fans. It's a big thing to him. He was a big mover in getting all our games sold out the first week in September, so they could all be televised."
 
A Boston Plan Hampered by Missteps
 At the same time, as his peers in the N.F.L. accepted publicly financed stadiums -- like Art Modell, who moved his Cleveland franchise to Baltimore in exchange for a new ball park -- Mr. Kraft, who was willing to raise the money for a stadium privately, would complain to friends about the ingratitude of Massachusetts politicians.
"I was willing to spend hundreds of millions of my own money to privately finance a stadium," he wrote in the newspaper advertisement last Sunday, "but was never given the opportunity."
His stadium hunt degenerated in Boston beginning in late 1995, after the Massachusetts House rejected a proposed domed stadium and convention center complex. Mr. Kraft came up with a plan to build a downtown open-air stadium without public subsidies.
But the plan, which relied on one-time fees charged to season ticketholders, was overshadowed by a series of political missteps that left even Mr. Kraft's supporters bemoaning his political naivete and his tendency to ignore advice and to turn on his allies. At one point, for example, he claimed that the Governor at the time, Mr. Weld, had guaranteed to deliver him a new stadium, saying that promise had "induced" him to take the risk of buying the Patriots. Yet a seventh grader could have told Mr. Kraft that such a promise was meaningless without the cooperation of the Legislature.
Eventually, what had made Mr. Kraft seem so endearing a few years earlier began to turn off those who dealt with him at the bargaining table. Thomas M. Finneran, the Speaker of the Massachusetts House, who became his chief adversary, called Mr. Kraft a "whiny millionaire."
In trying for more than a year to build a stadium in South Boston, associates of Mr. Kraft said he made the mistake of believing that if he could persuade the community's political leaders to accept his plan, residents would follow. But residents bridled at that presumption, as much as at the notion of game-day traffic jams in their neighborhood. The South Boston plan went down in flames and ill will in early 1997.
In Massachusetts, Mr. Kraft had often expressed a wish that a deal could be struck if he got all the most powerful politicians in one room. In Connecticut, he was proved right. After a series of secret meetings with Gov. John G. Rowland that began in May, the two reached agreement over the weekend of Nov. 14 and 15. The following Monday, Mr. Rowland met with all six legislative leaders to gain their support, and Mr. Kraft came by to answer their questions.
His deal with Connecticut in hand, Mr. Kraft immediately set out to persuade fans that he had done right by them. In a letter to season ticketholders mailed Nov. 19, he noted that they would not have to pay extra fees to retain their seats in Hartford, vowed there would be room at the new stadium for tailgating, and even promised that the new parking lots would empty in less than an hour, a vast improvement over Foxboro.
But that was not enough for Mr. Kraft: last Sunday, in his newspaper ads, he defended the move.
"I love Massachusetts" he wrote. "It has been home to my family all our lives. I wanted nothing more than to keep the Patriots here. It was simply impossible to do so and fulfill my obligation to continue to put a championship-caliber team on the field."

HEADLINE: The Neediest Cases;
Children Write Letters to Santa Asking for Help, Not Toys

BYLINE: By ADAM GERSHENSON 

 BODY:
As the holiday shopping season began last week, shoppers had nearly unlimited choices, from the newest Barbie to Interactive Barney to an $18,000 toy Range Rover, for those with unlimited means.
But for Amanda Lee Bernabe, 7, all of these presents are out of reach. Her family could afford little more than the 32-cent stamp for her letter from the Bronx to the local office of Santa Claus: the Children's Aid Society at 105 East 22d Street. 
 "Santa this year was very sad and very hard for us," she wrote. "Santa I lost my grandmother and I lost my house. My house got on fire and my mother lost her job. My mother is very sad that she don't have any Christmas spirit."
Amanda did not even ask for a Barbie doll or Nintendo 64. She wanted clothes for herself and her 5-year-old brother.
"It's as if there are two sets of holidays these days, one for rich kids and one for poor," said Philip Coltoff, the executive director of the Children's Aid Society. "We try to build a bridge between the two."
That bridge is supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, which sponsors seven local charities, including the Children's Aid Society, the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies and UJA-Federation of New York.
The fund, which begins its 87th annual appeal today, was created in 1912 by Adolph S. Ochs, then publisher of The Times, who had been moved by a chance encounter on Christmas Day, 1911, with a shabby beggar. Mr. Ochs had so much; the beggar had so little. The fund was established so New Yorkers with money could help those who had none.
The same kind of encounter could occur today at Grand Central Terminal, in Central Park, or on almost any corner in the city. Despite enormous disparities in income, rich and poor New Yorkers ride the same subways and use the same libraries. "New York City has a greater concentration of wealth and a greater concentration of poverty than anywhere in the state," said Frank Mauro, the director of the Fiscal Policy Institute, a research group that studies the New York economy.
The institute reported in September that although New York State's economy has rebounded in recent years, the benefits of this resurgence have not materialized for poor and middle-class families.
"Beneath the glittering picture of the New York City economy, the richest folks get the lion's share of it," said Larian Angelo, chief economist for the New York City Council.
Last year, 38 percent of the city's children lived in poverty, according to an analysis of the Census Bureau's March 1998 Current Population Survey done by the Community Service Society of New York. The census defined a family of three as living in poverty if its income was less than $12,391 a year.
The skewed income distribution may mean extravagant gifts in some wealthy families, but it means a lack of essentials -- and more reliance on charities -- for the poor.
The Neediest Cases Fund helps needy New Yorkers celebrate holidays with their children, but it also does much more.
At the Children's Aid Society, workers do not simply fulfill the holiday wish lists sent to Santa. They use the letters as initial assessments, then enroll a needy family in programs at one of their 36 community centers, which offer day care and after-school reading programs; dental, medical and mental health providers, and job training courses and employment opportunities for adults.
As a poor 4-year-old growing up in Harlem, Herman Bagley received a Christmas yo-yo from Children's Aid. Today, as an executive with the agency, he oversees the collection and distribution of 125,000 gifts a year.
This year, Mr. Bagley is worried that rising demand will overwhelm his agency's capacity to provide gifts.
"The intensity and demand has gone through the roof," said Mr. Bagley, as he eyed a handful of dusty skateboards and Hula-Hoops in an all-but-empty storage room for toys on East 22d Street.
Upstairs in his office, Mr. Bagley rifled through hundreds of letters that had recently arrived. Almost none of the children asked for exorbitant gifts, though a few held out hope for computers. Most requests were for jackets, boots and mittens. Other children wanted catcher's mitts, encyclopedias and bicycles.
Some boys and girls wrote that they had been good all year, and they wished for things no charity could provide, like a father or a mother.
But money from the Neediest Cases Fund will help in more tangible ways.
Last year readers of The New York Times contributed a record $5,811,568 to the fund. Generosity came in the form of $5 bills, and checks for $50,000, from schoolchildren and financiers.
The Times pays all the fund's administrative costs, so every dollar donated went directly to people in need, people like the children who had written to Mr. Bagley.
"All I want for Christmas is a bed," wrote one 9-year-old boy from Washington Heights.
"I would like some sweaters because winter is coming in and I get really cold," wrote Francisco Velez, 14, who also asked for "some pants, because mine are getting a little too old and tight."
Evelyn Duran of the Bronx wrote that she understood that even Santa, a man of supposedly unlimited resources, comes up short every now and again. "I would be happy with anything you send me," she wrote. "And if you can't, thank you anyways."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Herman Bagley, a director at the Children's Aid Society, in an almost bare stockroom. (Linda Rosier for The New York Times)

INTERNATIONAL 3-27
 
Jewish Organizations Fight Over Swiss Bank Proceeds
A battle is flaring between Jewish groups, plaintiffs' lawyers and concentration camp survivors over the $1.25 billion paid by Swiss banks to settle Holocaust-related lawsuits, and potentially billions more from claims against companies in Germany, Austria and other countries. 1
 
High-Level Purge in Belgrade
President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia has conducted an extraordinary purge of his innermost circle, dismissing the leaders of the army, the air force and the intelligence service as well as one of his most trusted political commissars. 1 

Swiss Vote on Legalizing Drugs
The Swiss are voting on whether to legalize everything from marijuana to heroin and cocaine, a measure that -- if passed -- would give Switzerland the most sweeping decriminalization of drug use, possession and production in Europe. 25
 
Congo Accord Is Reported
Leaders of Congo and neighboring countries giving support to armed rebels there agreed under United Nations auspices to sign a cease-fire by mid-December. President Jacques Chirac said that United Nations Secretary-General Kofi Annan had secured promises in meetings with eight African leaders in Paris for a summit meeting. 27
 
Italian Sentences Overturned
Italy's highest court overturned jail sentences for former Prime Minister Bettino Craxi and former Interior Minister Claudio Martelli on corruption charges. The court ruled that convictions of Mr. Craxi, Mr. Martelli and two other defendants were null and void and ordered a new appeals trial for the four. (Reuters)
 
NATIONAL 29-47
 
For Presidential Hopefuls, Fund-Raising Has Begun
Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska is engaged in the first test of the 2000 Presidential campaign: proving his ability to raise money. Like other Democratic and Republican hopefuls, he will have to raise more money than ever, at least $22 million, and earlier than ever before. So Senator Kerrey and six other Presidential aspirants have turned to so-called soft money -- large unrestricted contributions from wealthy individuals, corporations and labor unions. 1
 
Affirmative Action Debate
The longstanding debate over affirmative action in education, for years centered on universities and professional schools, is shifting to public school districts, where an increasing number of parents -- mostly white -- are complaining about policies they say are unfair to their children. Nearly a half-century after Brown v. Board of Education, the question of whether the educational value of diversity justifies race-conscious policies in public schools is an open one, never directly addressed by the United States Supreme Court. 1
 
Impeachment Inquiry Jockeying
As the House impeachment inquiry enters its crucial final weeks, Republicans and Democrats are jockeying for an advantage that could influence President Clinton's fate. Beginning on Monday, committee Republicans aim to shore up their case against Mr. Clinton by taking several steps, including a public hearing on the consequences of lying under oath. 47
 
New Housing Programs
President Clinton highlighted two new housing programs in his weekly radio address that will provide $822 million for low-income people who are elderly or disabled. 29
 
NEW YORK/REGION 49-57
 
Plastic Surgery for Teen-Agers Poses a Problem for Doctors
A generation ago, it was not unusual for some teen-agers to have their noses straightened or ears pinned back, but more controversial procedures, like breast augmentation, liposuction and tummy tucks, are gaining popularity these days in this impressionable age group. Doctors say the teen-age girls now flocking to the suites of plastic surgeons from Park Avenue to Beverly Hills pose an ethical problem. 1
 
A Takeover at Troubled Union
The parent union of District Council 37, New York City's largest municipal union, said yesterday that it was taking direct control of the council, effective tomorrow, to put an end to a spiraling scandal that has involved vote fraud and embezzlement. Gerald McEntee, president of the parent union, the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, named a trustee to run the council and said that Stanley Hill, the council's executive director, was taking a voluntary unpaid leave. 1
 
Patriots Owner Explains Deal
Robert K. Kraft, the owner of the New England Patriots, has gone to unusual lengths to explain his decision to accept Connecticut's offer to build his team a new stadium, one of the richest stadium deals any sports mogul had ever negotiated. Mr. Kraft, a native of Boston and loyal fan before he bought the Patriots, took out full-page advertisements in the Boston newspapers asking fans to understand his decision. He doesn't just want Connecticut's money; he wants to be forgiven for taking it. The situation embodies the opposing impulses -- one economic, the other emotional -- that are throwing dozens of cities into spasms of subsidized stadium construction and leaving others, deserted by their teams, wishing they had. 49

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
White Sox and Belle Made $100 Million Pact Possible

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
What hath Jerry Reinsdorf wrought?
The Chicago White Sox owner hasn't made a major free-agent signing in two years, but the last one he did, Albert Belle, triggered the escalating activity that reached a frenzy last week. Bernie Williams and Mo Vaughn, not to mention Mike Piazza, can nod in Reinsdorf's direction because his signing of Belle on Nov. 19, 1996, made their contracts possible. 
 Major League Baseball is hurtling toward its first $100 million contract, and while salaries have been escalating since free agency was created in 1976, the Belle contract thrust the salary scale into a higher orbit.
When bad Albert became a free agent following the 1996 season, the highest-paid player in baseball was Ken Griffey Jr., who earlier that year signed a four-year contract for $8.5 million a year. To put in perspective what Reinsdorf did for baseball contracts, it took four years to get from Ryne Sandberg's record $7.1 million to Griffey's $8.5 million, an increase of 19.7 percent.
If, in signing Belle, Reinsdorf had raised the scale by the same percentage, Belle would have received just under $10.2 million a year. But no reason to stop there. The White Sox owner asked Arn Tellem, Belle's agent, what he wanted, then gave it to him -- $11 million a year -- sending the top of the scale soaring by 29.4 percent only 10 months later.
In addition, Reinsdorf agreed to a clause that enabled Belle to become a free agent if three players had higher salaries. He is in that position now and has until Wednesday to decide if he wants to remain with the White Sox or go elsewhere. If it is elsewhere -- Baltimore -- he will do it for even more money than Reinsdorf gave him.
Tellem wanted the clause because he didn't know where the market was headed, and he wanted to make sure Belle suddenly didn't become underpaid. Any player who signs a long-term contract faces that possibility. But Reinsdorf wanted Belle so he capitulated on that issue, too.
Now Belle is in position to sign with the Orioles for $13 million a year for five years, which, at least for today, would place him in a tie for second for the highest annual average salary. Piazza ($13 million) eclipsed Pedro Martinez of Boston ($12.5 million) with his Mets' contract in October, then was supplanted himself last week when Vaughn ($13,333,333) signed with Anaheim.
Perhaps the most interesting aspect of the soaring, leapfrogging salaries at the upper end of the scale has been the silence of Griffey. Many consider him the best player in the game, but he has plummeted from No. 1 to a tie for 12th and he has never suggested that his contract be renegotiated to get him back to the top of the scale.
"You haven't heard him say anything; that's not his style," Woody Woodward, the Seattle general manager, said. "That's the way he's always been."
Griffey's contract expires after the 2000 season, the same time that his teammate, Alex Rodriguez, ends his contract. The Mariners are warily watching the salaries soar onward and upward. By the time Junior and A. Rod sign new contracts, they might own the Mariners' new park.
"I think we have the two best all-around players in the game," Woodward said, "looking at power, speed and defense, arms and the positions they play. My position has been and continues to be both of these fellows came through our system and I'd like to see them both finish their careers with Seattle."
 
Lack of Accountability
With a new seven-year contract in his pocket, Bernie Williams should finish his career with the Yankees. And every time he sees the Boston Red Sox, he should express his gratitude because they made it possible.
"Scott Boras wins again," an American League general manager said. "He had nothing until Dan Duquette." He referred to the Red Sox general manager.
"Duquette goes ahead and offers 87 and a half for Bernie on Tuesday and Wednesday the Yankees matched his mistake."
The Red Sox offered Williams $87.5 million for seven years. Two weeks earlier they offered Mo Vaughn $63 million for five years, and when he rejected it, they said bye, bye to one of the most popular athletes in Boston sports history, a player who had carried them on his burly back.
"I have no idea what's going through their heads," one general manager said.
"It doesn't make any sense," said an agent.
The Red Sox signing of Jose Offerman two weeks ago to a four-year, $26 million contract outraged other clubs.
"There is no accountability there," said an executive of a National League club. "They have no owner there. It's a trust."
The executive said he was told by the general manager of another club that one of Offerman's agents, in talking to clubs about the vastly improved infielder, sought less money than the Red Sox gave him.
"O'Leary, Wakefield, Garciaparra, Martinez, Offerman and he almost did it with Williams," an American League general manager said, rattling off names of players whose contracts other clubs found to be unnecessarily inflationary.
 
Tale of Two2 Contracts
The signing of Bernie Williams once again raised questions about the Yankees' practice of not signing their good young players to long-term contracts. The Cleveland Indians have followed the opposite practice, prompting other teams, such as the Angels, to sign their young players at least through the salary arbitration years.
A comparison between Williams and Jim Thome tells a revealing financial tale.
When Thome had between one and two years of major league service, the Indians signed him to a four-year contract. Then during the fourth year, in 1997, they signed him to a four-year extension. In the past five years they have paid Thome a total of $10.25 million.
Williams had between one and two years of major league service at the same time as Thome, entering the 1994 season.
There was no multiyear contract for Williams then; nor was there any until last week. Going year by year, the Yankees the past five years have paid Williams $17,225,000.
Some agents recommend that their clients shun multiyear contracts early in their careers. Thome's agent, in fact, urged him not to accept either contract. But the money and the security were too great for Thome to resist.
Now the Yankees have Derek Jeter and Mariano Rivera eligible for salary arbitration for the first time, and those players, as well as Andy Pettitte, remain unencumbered by a multiyear contract.
"We had some conversations last year and we agreed not to do it," Casey Close, Jeter's agent, said. "We couldn't agree on preliminary stuff. I expect they'll bring it up this year."
Even before Jeter and friends use the arbitration system, the Yankees have committed $66 million for 17 players for next season. They expect to have an opening-day payroll of about $81 million, up from a season-ending payroll of $65.6 million.
The only teams close to them in present payroll are Cleveland ($67.2 million for 18 players) and Atlanta ($65.65 million for 13 players).
 
No Conspiracy Theory
Contrary to the conspiracy theory espoused by some baseball executives last February, Scott Boras did not have a deal with the Arizona Diamondbacks to deliver Bernie Williams to them.
That so-called deal was the subject of hot speculation after the Diamondbacks signed Andy Benes, another Boras client, as a free agent. The expansion team, the theory went, helped Boras by signing Benes, and he, in turn, would make sure Williams signed with them this winter.
"It's logical for people to speculate in terms of Buck and Bernie," Colangelo said at the time, referring to his manager, Buck Showalter, who had been Williams's manager in New York. "Now there will be speculation because of the business I've done with Boras."
Colangelo was interested in Williams this month but never got serious enough with an offer to lure him to the Southwest.
In his effort to secure a record contract for Williams, Boras prepared a 23-page booklet of data on the center fielder. On one page, the agent got carried away. Citing his defensive ability, Boras said that Williams was ranked the major leagues' No. 1 center fielder in the Elias rankings, which are used to determine compensation for free agents. Williams was No. 1 all right, but not defensively.
The rankings use a complex formula based on a series of statistics, and in the case of outfielders, they are all hitting statistics -- plate appearances, batting average, on-base percentage, home runs and runs batted in.
No fly balls caught or missed, no assists, no errors.

Dropout U.S.A.

BYLINE: By ETHAN BRONNER

 BODY:
The United States no longer leads the world in the percentage of students graduating from high school.
A study by the 29-nation Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development shows that most industrialized nations have leapt ahead of this country and many will probably soon overtake it in college entry rates as well. 
Teacher pay as a percentage of national income is also lower and teacher workload higher than in many other comparable countries, the study found. ETHAN BRONNER
